. Since I wasn't sure myself, I looked up the definitions and difference between localization and internationalization.

Localization refers to the adaptation of a product, application or document content to meet the language, cultural and other requirements of a specific target market (a locale).
Internationalization is the design and development of a product, application or document content that enables easy localization for target audiences that vary in culture, region, or language.

By the way, I did this direct with zmq and jmp (no RxJS) and it worked just fine. Sample script:
``` javascript
const jmp = require('jmp');
const uuid = require('uuid');
const spawnteract = require('spawnteract');
const fs = require('fs');
const IOPUB = 'iopub';
const SHELL = 'shell';
const DEALER = 'dealer';
const SUB = 'sub';
const MESSAGE_EVENT = 'message';
const ZMQType = {
  frontend: {
    iopub: SUB,
    stdin: DEALER,
    shell: DEALER,
    control: DEALER,
  },
};
const session = uuid.v4();
function createMessage(msg_type) {
  const username = process.env.LOGNAME || process.env.USER ||
                   process.env.LNAME || process.env.USERNAME;
  return {
    header: {
      username,
      session,
      msg_type,
      msg_id: uuid.v4(),
      date: new Date(),
      version: '5.0',
    },
    metadata: {},
    parent_header: {},
    content: {},
  };
}
function createExecuteRequest(code) {
  const executeRequest = createMessage('execute_request');
  executeRequest.content = {
    code,
    silent: false,
    store_history: true,
    user_expressions: {},
    allow_stdin: false,
    stop_on_error: false,
  };
  return executeRequest;
}
function formConnectionString(config, channel) {
  const portDelimiter = config.transport === 'tcp' ? ':' : '-';
  const port = config[channel + '_port'];
  if (! port) {
    throw new Error(Port not found for channel "${channel}");
  }
  return ${config.transport}://${config.ip}${portDelimiter}${port};
}
function createSocket(channel, identity, config) {
  const zmqType = ZMQType.frontend[channel];
  const scheme = config.signature_scheme.slice('hmac-'.length);
  const socket = new jmp.Socket(zmqType, scheme, config.key);
  socket.identity = identity;
  socket.connect(formConnectionString(config, channel));
  return socket;
}
function main() {
  spawnteract.launch('python3').then(kernel => {
    const config = kernel.config;
    function cleanup() {
      kernel.spawn.kill();
      fs.unlink(kernel.connectionFile);
    }
    process.on('exit', cleanup);
    process.on('SIGINT', cleanup);
    const identity = uuid.v4();
    const iopubSocket = createSocket(IOPUB, identity, config);
    const shellSocket = createSocket(SHELL, identity, config);
    iopubSocket.on(MESSAGE_EVENT, (msg) => {
      console.log(msg);
    });
    shellSocket.on(MESSAGE_EVENT, (msg) => {
      console.log(msg);
    });
const msg = createExecuteRequest('print(2+2)');
shellSocket.send(new jmp.Message(msg));

});
}
main();
```

. I'd like to follow this one up with removing the need for an index (some sort of ref to a cell). Not sure how to do that, but I think it will lead to less asynchronous errors (what if a cell is in flight and does an update?)
. > So during save/load we'd strip/add these ref guids?
We'd have some way to go from our internal structure to the disk format. The current way to do it is to take the immutable.js notebook structure and run toJS(). We'd keep the API simple on the outside for our own contributor experience.
As for the internal structure, I'm not sure yet. When a cell gets new data (outputs, source/input, execution_count), the action we're aiming for is saying "this cell has updated" and all we have right now is the index that was supplied to the cell. It's tempting to use a uuid for each cell and map between the list of cells and the current cell version:
``` javascript
notebook = {
  cells: [id1, id2, id3, id4],
  ...
}
cells = {
  id1: cell1,
  id2: cell2,
  ...
}
```
This seems like it's adding indirection rather than solving the root problem. A cell still needs to know its ID (which could also be the key prop). This at least clarifies that the notebook is maintaining the ordering of cells while the cells map is able to track state of the individual cells over time. We have to maintain two data structures with this.

. Ok, I've noticed that beforeunload and unload events are both fired when you ctrl-c kill an application, as well as the rest of the quit action. What we're definitely running into though is that we've been relying on an asynchronous flow for killing the kernel. When these two are triggered, we need to handle them immediately.

. Ah, unless broken up by display data:

. We currently do an overall reduction on the outputs for all the relevant message types:
js
    // Handle all the nbformattable messages
    subscriptions.push(childMessages
         .ofMessageType(['execute_result', 'display_data', 'stream', 'error', 'clear_output'])
         .map(msgSpecToNotebookFormat)
         // Iteratively reduce on the outputs
         .scan((outputs, output) => {
           if (output.output_type === 'clear_output') {
             return new Immutable.List();
           }
           return outputs.push(Immutable.fromJS(output));
         }, new Immutable.List())
         // Update the outputs with each change
         .subscribe(outputs => {
           subscriber.next(updateCellOutputs(id, outputs));
         })
    );
whereas it seems like we'll need to do a scan on stream that merges in selectively or we reduce prior outputs delimited by display_data.

. Thank you for the feedback Min!
This at least makes me feel better about aggregating according to whichever came first. I was aiming to be as close to the notebook as possible while handling ANSI escape codes properly.

Alternately, you could completely ignore the difference between stdout and stderr, which is what a terminal does.

This made me curious about escape codes and how they're handled when mixed between stderr and stdout. Of course it's literally what you said. Example script:
``` python
from colorama import Fore, Back, Style
import sys
sys.stderr.write(Fore.BLUE + 'blue!\n')
sys.stderr.flush()
print(Style.DIM + 'STDOUT DIM')
print(Style.RESET_ALL)
sys.stderr.flush()
sys.stdout.flush()
print('back to normal now')
sys.stderr.write('woo\n')
```
Terminal output:

It's super simple to implement merging the streams in the frontend. However, that diverges from the notebook format. I honestly think that we would be able to support more escape codes in the frontend for view; complete with erase, cursor movement (for display), and text attributes.

I'm noticing the same thing, since we have to keep appending strings. It's making me want to explore another model.
The nice thing about semi-rigorous terminal-emulation is that we could reduce the final string to the representation that a terminal would show. This:
"\u001b[?25l\u001b[0G▄ ╢░╟\n\u001b[?25h\u001b[1A\u001b[?25l\u001b[0G▌ ╢░░╟\n"
becomes (roughly):
\"u001b[?25l\u001b[0G▌ ╢░░╟\n"
We then get "terminal animations" while the resulting notebook file is more compact (as well as in-memory representation).
. The way this differs from the Jupyter notebook is that stderr can be buffered before stdout (if it receives stderr first). This made the implementation simpler.

function tildify(home, p) {
  const s = path.normalize(p) + path.sep;
  return (s.indexOf(home) === 0 ? s.replace(home + path.sep, '~' + path.sep) : s).slice(0, -1);
}
and we're well on our way.

- using console.warn
- using console.error
- popping up a dialog box using native electron APIs
- using eslint disable line

. This makes me realize we were operating on the wrong version of the format I think. The top level structure for this metadata should be:
js
{
  "metadata" : {
    "kernel_info": {
        # if kernel_info is defined, its name field is required.
        "name" : "the name of the kernel"
    },
    "language_info": {
        # if language_info is defined, its name field is required.
        "name" : "the programming language of the kernel",
        "version": "the version of the language",
        "codemirror_mode": "The name of the codemirror mode to use [optional]"
    }
  },
  "nbformat": 4,
  "nbformat_minor": 0,
  "cells" : [
      # list of cell dictionaries, see below
  ],
}

JupyterLab already has a notebook plugin. What does nteract's notebook solve that is not addressed in JupyterLab's notebook?
. The nteract desktop app's primary goal is to only serve as an editor for notebook files. This means that you have to use a text editor for your non-notebook scripts, a native terminal for the terminal experience, and your native OS file manager for navigating.
If you want a desktop app for JupyterLab itself, you should push for them to make an Electron app or lend a hand with them to package up an Electron app (what nteract relies on).. . I love regex.
However, we have to take a step back here to understand and resolve the core problem while assisting the user as much as possible. Spaces have a specific meaning in Markdown URLs both in CommonMark and the original Markdown "spec":

To create an inline link, use a set of regular parentheses immediately after the link text’s closing square bracket. Inside the parentheses, put the URL where you want the link to point, along with an optional title for the link, surrounded in quotes. For example:
This is [an example](http://example.com/ "Title") inline link.
[This link](http://example.net/) has no title attribute.

A URL with spaces is not a valid URL. The URL with %20 is URL encoded, quite valid. There is an important reason to support the title attribute - for accessibility and screen readers. This becomes more important when doing links on images from Markdown.
. In this case, I think the original jupyter notebooks (that I see above) need to be patched to match the markdown standards. If you copy a URL directly in Chrome that has spaces (assuming you're on the page, not that you've just typed it), Chrome copies the URL encoded form of the link.

. I'm not sure where this would belong. I'd rather we finish off handling line feeds and other ANSI/terminal codes before we add automatic linkification.
. While convenient to use the linkify, it comes at the cost of reducing what can be displayed in untrusted notebooks. All outputs from streams would not be shown on opening the notebook.
. Yeah, an approach that keeps content as textContent, can be displayed. When strings are the children of a React Element, they are done as textContent which is what you've done above.
There's going to be some amount of tripping on escape codes here. An admittedly naive approach that would keep the console consistent would be to do a second pass on the bundles returned by ansiToJson.
As for rolling our own, I recall ~Hyperterm~ Hyper.app talking about trying to do terminal state in a way where they could push down state into a React component more effectively. At a high level, the current state of the terminal is an intermediate reduction on the stream of character. Stepping out of that abstract way to say it, I wish we had a function with a signature like this:
function ttyReducer(state: ttyState, text): ttyState
Where ttyState is (in all likelihood) a string. This is important to me because we'd be able to store the last state in the notebook document rather than the entire stream of text from stdout.

Remote kernels

/cc @craigcitro. Turn
js
export const publishEpic = (action$, store) =>
  const boundHandleGistError = handleGistError.bind(null, store);
  action$.ofType(PUBLISH_USER_GIST, PUBLISH_ANONYMOUS_GIST)
    .mergeMap((action) => handleGistAction(action, store))
    .catch(boundHandleGistError(err));
into
js
export const publishEpic = (action$, store) => {
  const boundHandleGistError = handleGistError.bind(null, store);
  return action$.ofType(PUBLISH_USER_GIST, PUBLISH_ANONYMOUS_GIST)
    .mergeMap((action) => handleGistAction(action, store))
    .catch(boundHandleGistError(err));
}
The reason is that the arrow function without braces is an expression.
js
() => 2
is equivalent to
js
() => {
  return 2
}
As soon as you need more than one statement you have to use the braces and write an explicit return (if you need it):
js
export const publishEpic = (action$, store) => {
  const boundHandleGistError = handleGistError.bind(null, store);
  return action$.ofType(PUBLISH_USER_GIST, PUBLISH_ANONYMOUS_GIST)
    .mergeMap((action) => handleGistAction(action, store))
    .catch(boundHandleGistError(err));
}

. To play with this PR, in your notebook you'll want:
``` python
from IPython.display import display
ip = get_ipython()
iopub = ip.kernel.iopub_socket
session = ip.kernel.session
def display_with_id(obj, display_id, update=False):
    """Create a new display with an id"""
    data, md = ip.display_formatter.format(obj)
    transient = {'display_id': display_id}
    content = {
        'data': data,
        'metadata': md,
        'transient': transient,
    }
    msg_type = 'update_display_data' if update else 'display_data'
    session.send(iopub, msg_type, content, parent=ip.parent_header)
def update_display(obj, display_id):
    """Update existing displays with id"""
    return display_with_id(obj, display_id, update=True)
```
ProgressBar, traitlets based
``` python
import os
from binascii import hexlify
import time
import traitlets
from traitlets import observe, Int, HasTraits
class ProgressBar(HasTraits):
    capacity = Integer(100, help="capacity for progress")
    progress = Integer(0, help="value of progress")
def __init__(self, capacity):
    self._display_id = hexlify(os.urandom(8)).decode('ascii')

def _repr_html_(self):
    return "<progress max='{}' value='{}'></progress>".format(self.capacity, self.progress)

def display(self):
    display_with_id(self, display_id=self._display_id)

@observe('capacity', 'progress')
def update(self, change):
    update_display(self, display_id=self._display_id)

```
Invoking:
``` python
bar = ProgressBar(100)
bar.display()
for i in range(101):
    bar.progress = i
    time.sleep(0.01)
```
Emoji Updater, also traitlets based
``` python
import os
from binascii import hexlify
from traitlets import observe, HasTraits
class Emoji(HasTraits):
    emoji = traitlets.Unicode('😁', help="emoji to show")
def __init__(self):
    self._display_id = hexlify(os.urandom(8)).decode('ascii')

def _repr_html_(self):
    return '<h1 style="font-size: 100px">{}</h1>'.format(self.emoji)

def display(self):
    display_with_id(self, display_id=self._display_id)

@observe('emoji')
def update(self, change):
    update_display(self, display_id=self._display_id)

em = Emoji()
em.display()
```
Invoking:
python
emojis = "😃😄😅😆😃"
for i in emojis:
    em.emoji = i
    time.sleep(0.5)

In the meantime, here's a function that will work with plotly data and layout objects:
```python
import IPython
import plotly
import json
def plotize(data, layout=None):
  """Plot with Plotly.js using the Plotly JSON Chart Schema
http://help.plot.ly/json-chart-schema/
  """
  if layout is None:
    layout = {}
redata = json.loads(json.dumps(data, cls=plotly.utils.PlotlyJSONEncoder))
  relayout = json.loads(json.dumps(layout, cls=plotly.utils.PlotlyJSONEncoder))
bundle = {}
  bundle['application/vnd.plotly.v1+json'] = {
    'data': redata,
    'layout': relayout,
  }
IPython.display.display(bundle, raw=True)
```

In order to have Python kernels be detected, they need to be installed in a similar manner as the R kernel:
python -m pip install ipykernel
python -m ipykernel install --user
This installs a kernelspec for Python. You can also run ipykernel with options, including the name you want to make the kernel (in case you want individual ones for conda environments).
In the long run once https://github.com/nteract/nteract/pull/1264 is finished up, there are small PRs ahead to detect and use the default Python kernel as well as conda environments.. That ipykernel command places a kernel.json file in the jupyter kernels directory. In a coming release we'll do detection of a python installation that doesn't include the kernel.json.

This makes for good reasoning why we want setIn and not allowing push as a mechanic.. Concrete example of updating the user's model after working through it with @peggyrayzis:
In the user's output is a slider that controls r and the view of an image called image. The model ID will be my-image-model for this little example.
js
models = {
  'my-image-model': {
    'image': 'binaryData...',
    'r': 200,
  }
}
When user slides slider r, we emit a Redux action like:
js
{
  type: "UPDATE_USER_MODEL",
  modelID: 'my-image-model',
  value: "200",
  path: ["r"]
}
Within reducers, modify ['models', modelID, "r"], updating the value for r in the model while also sending a COMM_MESSAGE to the backend to also update the model in the kernel.
The kernel responds by sending a COMM_MESSAGE with { "path": ["r"], value: "200" }
and then also sends the a COMM_MESSAGE with a payload for the modified image:
js
{ "path": ["image"], value: "somebinarydata" }

One annoyance on OS X is that it invokes Applications with launchctl and does not create a shell for you. The shell-env was put in place to work around this issue by spawning a shell for the user.
I'm installing Tensorflow on my mac now, I've only used it on remote systems prior to this.. Side question so that I can experience this - what kind of Mac do you have, what GPU do you use? My Macbook Pro (2015 model) only has the built in Intel GPU, and the newer Macs use AMD GPUs.
As for if you're able to extract the LD_LIBRARY_PATH, my first thought is adding to https://github.com/nteract/nteract/blob/2fec84bd74d92b8be88f6c9399e59993f703b59a/src/main/prepare-env.js#L5
Off the cuff, I'm guessing it would look something like:
```js
import shellEnv from "shell-env";
import Rx from "rxjs/Rx";
const spawn = require("spawn-rx").spawn;
/*
 * Observable of environment variable mappings
 * @param  {string} name environment variable name e.g. LD_LIBRARY_PATH
 * @return {Object}      { [name]: env_var_value }
 /
function extractEnvVariable(name: string) {
  return spawn("bash", ["-c", echo $${name}]).map(
    value => value === "" ? {} : { [name]: value }
  );
}
let env$ = Rx.Observable.fromPromise(shellEnv());
// Possibly a workaround
if (process.platform === "darwin") {
  env$ = Rx.Observable
    .merge(
      env$,
      extractEnvVariable("LD_LIBRARY_PATH"),
      extractEnvVariable("DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH")
    )
    .reduce((env, moreEnv) => Object.assign({}, env, moreEnv));
}
const createEnv$ = env$
  .first()
  .do(env => {
    Object.assign(process.env, env);
  })
  .publishReplay(1);
createEnv$.connect();
export default createEnv$;
```

The main way that jupyter does multiple outputs is with display_data messages. Roughly, they look like this:
```
display_data.content: {
  data: {
    'text/html': 'hey'
  }
}
display_data.content: {
  data: {
    'text/html': 'woo'
  }
}
```
Recently, update_display_data was added which allows for updating prior displays by way of a display_id inside the transient field:
```
display_data.content: {
  data: {
    'text/html': 'hey'
  },
  transient: {
    'display_id': '1234'
  }
}
update_display_data.content: {
  data: {
    'text/html': 'HEY'
  },
  transient: {
    'display_id': '1234'
  }
}
```

Ok now that I've had a go at this for a bit, it's definitely seeming like we'd need to approach parts of this differently:
Long term plan
JS output and HTML output should have the same output context / area. This likely means doing a unified iframed (webview for electron) display area. We'd still inject dependencies (vega, plotly, etc.)
Short term plan
Provide document and window to the "sandbox" so we don't break current functionality. The only thing that's changing here is that we're providing a requirejs "shim" of sorts and for Atom, we'll be using vm. We'll also be able to provide better error messages for use of objects we don't have (e.g. IPython, Jupyter).. Once this passes, it's ready to go and provides us a nice path for supporting vega/altair, d3, and informing users in a much richer way about what we can and can't support.. Whoa! In the original package:
```
git checkout -b move-to-monorepo
mkdir -p packages/NAME
git mv !(packages) packages/NAME/
git mv .SOMEFILE packages/NAME # Catch the dotfiles
Double check things first
git commit -am "preparing NAME for move to monorepo"
```
In the monorepo (on branch "another-merger")
```
git remote add tmpNAME /Path/To/NAME
git fetch tmpNAME
git merge tmpNAME/move-to-monorepo --allow-unrelated-histories
Make commit message be:
chore: merge X into monorepo
``. It should be easy to import the other 3 now, not a big deal at the moment though.. Finally bot, I agree with you. We likelywontfixthese. 😄 . Now, I don't know how often this ends up being actually used in practice, 
but at least in theory this is a totally generic thing, where you create a 
"union" of two git trees. I did the union merge manually, but in theory it 
should be easy to automate, with simply something like

git fetch <project-to-union-merge>
    GIT_INDEX_FILE=.git/tmp-index git-read-tree FETCH_HEAD
    GIT_INDEX_FILE=.git/tmp-index git-checkout-cache -a -u
    git-update-cache --add -- (GIT_INDEX_FILE=.git/tmp-index git-ls-files)
    cp .git/FETCH_HEAD .git/MERGE_HEAD
    git commit

(this is not exactly how I did it, but that's just because I'd never done
this before so I didn't think it through and I had some stupid extra steps
in between that were unnecessary).

I'll describe this on a components level (per project / concept), then we can tie it all together.
Commuter API Endpoint
Publishing a new notebook (or an old one for that matter) as a new published entity:
POST /api/v1/published/
{notebook content, could be similar to the contents API}
Response:
{
  id: "the-id-of-the-published-document",
  version: "1", # This could be a hash of the notebook too
  url: "", # Path to the notebook, for linking out to
}
Publishing a new version of a notebook
PUT /api/v1/published/123
{notebook content}
Response is similar to the POST
Notebook metadata
A published notebook updates metadata under .metadata.papermill.publish
js
{
  cells: [...],
  metadata: {
    papermill: {
      publication: {
        id: "1234",
        endpoint: "https://mycommuter"
      }
    }
  }
}
This captures the endpoint so that publishing again will update the published copy, allowing an author to iterate and publish again.
Clients - nteract, papermill
nteract will include a button to publish, including a way to set up credentials
papermill will have a publish command like so:
papermill publish myNotebook.ipynb
They both modify the notebook in place to include the above mentioned metadata.
Versioning
In terms of UI on commuter, I want people to be able to:

Link to a published notebook
Link to a specific version of a published notebook (by hash or version number)
Publish from the commuter browsing interface straight to published

Opinions on getting started with storage and indexing

As for the Jupyter directories, nteract adheres to the Jupyter file paths (or at least purports to). You can set environment variables to override JUPYTER_CONFIG_DIR for Jupyter and IPYTHONDIR for IPython. The second one is created by IPython, not by nteract. There is a difference when running nteract vs. the notebook in a conda environment, since it will use the sys prefix within the conda env.
Overriding IPYTHONDIR
The kernel for the conda environment can set keys in env, including where you want the IPYTHONDIR to be. Example:
js
{
 "argv": [
  "C:\/python\/python",
  "-m",
  "ipykernel_launcher",
  "-f",
  "{connection_file}"
 ],
 "env": {
  "IPYTHONDIR": "C:\/temp"
 },
 "display_name": "Python 3",
 "language": "python"
}
Admittedly I don't know where you'd pick the temp dir or how the paths would look inside the JSON without my Windows machine with me.
Overriding JUPYTER_CONFIG_DIR
The only option I can think of here is to either:

modify the global environment variable (this seems rough considering the restrictions on the school systems)
create a shortcut to the app that sets the environment variable (at least I think this was available)

We can hyper optimize later by only storing a hash of the notebook object. Since our Immutable.js structure is impure (the mutable data objects within display_data), I'm not sure if the iterable.hashCode() will be valid.. Sure enough, can't use hashCode for fast comparisons because of the mutable leaf nodes:
```js

m = Immutable.Map({'a': {'b': 2}}) // the top level is immutable here
Map { "a": [object Object] }
m.get('a') // The inner object is mutable
{ b: 2 }
m.get('a')['b']
2
m.hashCode()
-356504055
m.get('a')['b'] = 3
3
m.hashCode()
-356504055
```

Maybe it's not a big deal since display updates actively change that entire data payload.. > I don't know if there is a canonical for these kind of tasks in redux.
Non-redux, had we stuck with full immutable
If the full structure was Immutable.js, then you'd only store the notebook.hashCode() for the saved notebook and compare it to the notebook.hashCode() for the current notebook. I'm only noting this to show what the benefit of truly immutable data structures are (when deeply immutable).
Redux way (proposal)

You can do direct equality between two notebooks made with commutable using Immutable's isEqual:

notebook.isEqual(otherNotebook)
or
Immutable.is(notebook, otherNotebook)
This is a fast O(1) computation because it's checking the hashCode between the two objects. It has some caveats to it though:

The notebook itself needs to be a fully immutable object for this to be accurate
This is useful for in-memory comparisons (has the notebook changed), not for comparing two notebooks on disk

Generally speaking, commutable is a utility wrapper around immutable setting up an opinionated data structure. What we probably need to do is link out to Immutable docs more. With that, I'll answer a few of the others:
function getCellById(notebook, id) {
  return notebook.getIn(['cellMap', id])
}
function getCellByIndex(notebook, index) {
  const id = notebook.getIn(['cellOrder', index]);
  return notebook.getIn(['cellMap', id])
}
Those would probably be fine to add to commutable itself. They're definitely useful for testing, though I imagine I probably wouldn't use them in applications built on top of commutable because I tend to use updateIn for performance when I have multiple operations on the document.

I'm sure commutable isn't meant to be tied to nteract.

Ok, everything is in a really good state except one... It's one of my favorite themes,theme-nteract.css`. 
The nteract theme (not to be confused with the default which is called light) does a bunch of deeply nested changes that are dependent on the original DOM structure. I'm tempted to bring in some of the opinionated styling from the nteract theme into the base components (especially the barbershop stripes).

All the changes (open me)

```
/*
  General note on this theme: the class "notebook" is used before several
  selectors to override collisions with the main stylesheet. Instead of adding
  !important on al the things, .notebook makes these selectors more specific.
*/

/* -------------------- */
/* Focus on Active Card */
/* -------------------- */

.cell,
.notebook .cell:focus,
.notebook .cell.focused {
  box-shadow: var(--small-shadow);
}

.notebook .cell:hover {
  box-shadow: var(--large-shadow);
}

.cell:focus .cm-s-composition.CodeMirror,
.cell.focused .cm-s-composition.CodeMirror,
.cell.focused .rendered {
  background: var(--cell-bg);
}

.outputs,
.CodeMirror-lines {
  opacity: 0.75;
}

.cell .rendered {
  background: var(--cm-background);
}

.cell:focus .CodeMirror-lines,
.cell.focused .CodeMirror-lines,
.cell.focused .outputs,
.cell.focused .rendered {
  opacity: 1;
  color: var(--main-fg-color);
}

.cell.focused .input-container {
  box-shadow: var(--small-shadow);
}

/* -------------------------- */
/* CodeMirror Colors & Styles */
/* -------------------------- */

.cm-property {
  color: #9cafea;
}

.cm-comment {
  font-style: italic;
  opacity: 0.3;
}

.CodeMirror-selected,
.CodeMirror-focused .CodeMirror-selected {
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);
}

.cm-s-composition span.cm-string.cm-url {
  color: var(--cm-link);
  opacity: 0.5;
}

/* Override Inline Styles */
/* These styles are used for code errors in the CodeMirror output */

span[style="color: rgb(187, 0, 0);"] {
  color: var(--cm-keyword) !important;
  font-weight: bold;
}

span[style="color: rgb(0, 187, 0);"] {
  color: var(--cm-string) !important;
}

span[style="color: rgb(0, 187, 187);"] {
  color: var(--main-fg-color) !important;
}

span[style="color: rgb(0, 0, 187);"] {
  color: inherit !important;
}

span[style="color: rgb(0, 255, 0);"] {
  color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.3) !important;
}

/* ---------------------- */
/* Markdown & Text Styles */
/* ---------------------- */

.outputs a,
.rendered a {
  color: var(--cm-link);
}

.outputs > div {
  background-color: rgba(29, 49, 76, 0.7);
}

/* Tables */

th,
.th {
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.25);
}

tr:nth-of-type(even),
.tr:nth-of-type(even) {
  background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.075);
}

tr:hover,
.tr:hover {
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
}

/* Blockquotes */

.notebook blockquote::before {
  content: "";
  background-color: var(--cm-special);
  background-size: 10px 10px;
  background-image: linear-gradient(
    45deg,
    rgba(27, 42, 62, 0.2) 25%,
    transparent 25%,
    transparent 50%,
    rgba(27, 42, 62, 0.2) 50%,
    rgba(27, 42, 62, 0.2) 75%,
    transparent 75%,
    transparent
  );
  width: 0.75rem;
  height: 100%;
  display: block;
  margin: 0;
  position: absolute;
  left: 0;
  top: 0;
}

.notebook blockquote {
  position: relative;
  border: 0;
  margin-left: 0;
  padding-left: 1.5rem;
}

/* Lists */

ul li {
  list-style: none;
}

ul li::before {
  content: "\f078";
  font: normal normal normal 16px/1 octicons;
  display: inline-block;
  text-decoration: none;
  text-rendering: auto;
  -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;
  -moz-osx-font-smoothing: grayscale;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  text-indent: -1rem;
  color: var(--cm-special);
}

/* --------------------------- */
/* Create & Edit Cell Toolbars */
/* --------------------------- */

.notebook .cell-creator,
.cell-toolbar {
  padding: 0.125em 0.25em;
  box-shadow: var(--small-shadow);
}

.notebook .cell-creator:hover,
.cell-toolbar:hover {
  box-shadow: var(--large-shadow);
}

.notebook .cell-creator {
  background: var(--toolbar-bg);
  border-radius: var(--border-radius);
}

.cell-toolbar {
  border-radius: 0 0 0 var(--border-radius);
  padding: 0.125em 0.25em;
}

/* ------------ */
/* Sticky Cells */
/* ------------ */

.notebook .sticky-cell-container {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
  box-shadow: var(--large-shadow);
  z-index: 2000;
}

.sticky-cell-container > div ~ div {
  margin-top: 2rem;
}

/* The container itself has a shadow, so let's kill the shadow on the last box */

.sticky-cell-container .cell:last-of-type {
  box-shadow: none !important;
}

.sticky-cell-container .stickyButton span {
  color: var(--cm-special);
}

/* ------------- */
/* Running Cells */
/* ------------- */

@keyframes striperunner {
  from {
    background-position: 0 0;
  }
  to {
    background-position: 60px 30px;
  }
}

/*
  This value is declared here to avoid a weird display blip where the size is
  set on .cell-running .prompt AFTER the gradient is applied, resulting in
  huge stripes
*/
.cell .prompt {
  background-size: 30px 30px;
}

.cell-running .prompt {
  background-image: linear-gradient(
    45deg,
    rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.1) 25%,
    transparent 25%,
    transparent 50%,
    rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.1) 50%,
    rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.1) 75%,
    transparent 75%,
    transparent
  );
  animation: striperunner 1.5s linear infinite;
}

/* ---------------- */
/* Dropdown Content */
/* ---------------- */

.notebook .dropdown__content {
  top: 0.75rem;
  border-radius: var(--border-radius) 0 0 var(--border-radius);
  box-shadow: var(--small-shadow);
}

.notebook .dropdown__content li {
  padding: 0.5rem;
}

.dropdown__content li:before {
  display: none;
}

/* -------------------- */
/*   Printing Styles    */
/* -------------------- */
@media print {
  .cell:focus .cm-s-composition.CodeMirror,
  .cell.focused .cm-s-composition.CodeMirror,
  .cell.focused .rendered {
    background: var(--cm-background);
  }
}

/* -------------------- */
/* Miscellaneous Styles */
/* -------------------- */

.cell .prompt,
.notebook .cell-creator,
button,
a,
tr {
  transition: all 0.1s ease-in-out;
}

/*custom scrollbar for notebook cells and hint box*/
div::-webkit-scrollbar,
ul::-webkit-scrollbar {
  width: 11px;
  height: 11px;
}
div::-webkit-scrollbar-track,
ul::-webkit-scrollbar-track {
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);
}
div::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb,
ul::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb {
  background-color: rgba(237, 243, 247, 0.6);
}
div::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:hover,
ul::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:hover {
  background-color: rgba(237, 243, 247, 0.7);
}
div::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:active,
ul::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:active {
  background-color: rgba(237, 243, 247, 0.9);
}
div::-webkit-scrollbar-corner,
ul::-webkit-scrollbar-corner {
  background-color: transparent;
}
```

```js
const { binder } = require("rx-binder");
import { kernels } from "rx-jupyter";
import { filter, switchMap } from "rxjs/operators";
binder({ repo: "nteract/vdom" }).pipe(
  filter(m => m.phase === "ready"),
  switchMap(msg => {
    const serverConfig = {
      endpoint: msg.url,
      token: msg.token
    };
return kernels.start(serverConfig, "python3", "/");

})
);
```

Yeah, after successful shutdown (with that killServerFulfilled) we'd have to update the reducers to use that action to ~delete~ omit that server. Normally, if you want to delete a key out of an object, you use delete. With our store though, we shouldn't mutate state directly:
```js

x = {'a': 2}
{a: 2}
delete x['a'] // Let's not do this
true
x
{}
```

I tend to use omit from lodash for this:
```js

import { omit } from 'lodash'
x = {'a': 2}
{ a: 2 }
omit(x, 'a')
{}
x
{ a: 2 }
```. Since we just hashed this out a bit in chat, I'll port over the convo:

```js

var Rx = require('rxjs/Rx');
undefined
var obs = Rx.Observable.interval(2000).map(i => i*100)
undefined
var subscription = obs.subscribe(x => console.log(x))
undefined
0
100
200
subscription.unsubscribe()
``. It's the component you'd wrap around the` instance like this:

js
<Editor>

</Editor>
Whereas if you were merely showing it as a read-only display you'd use:
js

  {source}
</Editor>
The component primarily exists to make sure that the style stays consistent between static rendering and codemirror rendering, while also working in tandem with the <Prompt /> and overall <Input /> component:
js
<Input hidden={sourceHidden}>
  <Prompt />
  <Editor>
    <CodeMirror
      tip
      completion
      id={cellID}
      value={source}
      language={this.props.language}
      cellFocused={this.props.cellFocused}
      editorFocused={this.props.editorFocused}
      theme={this.props.theme}
      focusAbove={this.focusAboveCell}
      focusBelow={this.focusBelowCell}
    />
  </Editor>
</Input>

User clicks New ˅
A GET for each of Contents (on /), Sessions, and Terminals is done
The Contents one is notable here because the new notebook is created to be a one-up from the last Untitled${number}.ipynb
A POST to /api/contents/Untitled${number}.ipynb is performed with payload:

js
{ "type": "notebook" }

Note: :warning: possible race condition possible between when the directory listing is performed and when this new notebook is created. This is probably more likely with multiple notebook servers running at the same location (NFS, EFS backed)
The user is redirected to /notebooks/Untitled${number}.ipynb
POST to /api/sessions with:

js
{
  path: `Untitled4.ipynb`,
  type: "notebook",
  name: "",
  kernel: {
    id: null,
    name: "python3"
  }
}

Server responds with the created session and kernel:

{
  id: "35aeee00-79f9-43ad-b674-20618d91adf5",
  path: "Untitled4.ipynb",
  name: "",
  type: "notebook",
  kernel: {
    id: "816af886-ede7-47bd-bc93-6cdcfe7fedd2",
    name: "python3",
    last_activity: "2018-02-14T21:34:49.945834Z",
    execution_state: "starting",
    connections: 0
  },
  notebook: { path: "Untitled4.ipynb", name: "" }
}

Channels are connected to, noting that the session_id is not the same as the session's id .____.
Contents are fetched

Stability

Accessibilty

Notebook selection menu (#2623)

Big repo changes

No more @nteract/types module

js
const autoSaveEpic = (action$, state$) =>
  action$.pipe(
    ofType(AUTO_SAVE_ENABLE),
    // The use of an exhaustMap here is basically a flipped switch to say
    // "we are in autosaving mode, don't re-enable it again until requested"
    exhaustMap(() =>
      state$.pipe(
        // Note that our setup is a little more complex because we have multiple documents (potentially)
        // and are autosaving per contentRef
        pluck('content'),
        distinctUntilChanged(),
        throttleTime(500, { leading: false, trailing: true }),
        concatMap(content =>
          saveContent(content).pipe(
            map(() => saveContentFulfilled()),
            catchError(e => of(saveContentRejected(e)))
          )
        ),
        takeUntil(action$.pipe(
          ofType(AUTO_SAVE_DISABLE)
        ))
      )
    )
  );

The implementation we ended up at was something like this:
```js
const originalWebsocket = webSocket(
  formWebSocketURL(serverConfig, kernelID, sessionID)
);
const wsSubject = merge(
  originalWebsocket,
  timer(5000).pipe(
    exhaustMap(() => {
      const waitTime = 10000;
  originalWebsocket.next(heartBeatMessage);

  return throwError(`timed out after ${waitTime} ms`).pipe(
    timeout(waitTime),
    // Effectively, if we get _any_ message we assume that the connection is live
    takeUntil(originalWebsocket)
  );
})
// Somehow this needs to cause a reconnection

)
);
```

When a kernel gets connected, it sends all messages in batched collections as a new action:
type BatchedJupyterMessages = {
  type: "BATCHED_JUPTYER_MESSAGE_ACTION"
  payload: {
    contentRef: ContentRef,
    messages: Array<JupyterMessage>
  }
}
These then get routed to the contents model that is the intended receiver. Since this is now devoid of a CellId, we have to do a different kind of tracking. Within the notebook for instance, the last execute message id would need to be tracked for each cell (this is similar to how the classic notebook does the tracking). We then drop any messages that aren't "assigned" anywhere.
I'm guessing that the generic action that needs to be sent is:
type SendExecuteRequest = {
  payload: {
    contentRef: ContentRef,
    message: JupyterMessage
  }
}
What I'm a bit unsure of is how we'd track the CellID for the notebook. There seem to be a few options -- we could store some info in a metadata field in that SendExecuteRequest action or we can create this new action from the ol' execute cell action. 💭 . We... have a bit of a crazy monorepo, though it works well for us. We use mostly stock lerna for our setup. Within lerna terms, we have two different sets of packages, packages and applications. Everything in packages we ❤️ being able to edit along with the applications that use them, while also making sure that we transpile the versions we publish. ```

```js
// react-hot-loader uses proxies to the original elements so we need to use
// their comparison function in case a consumer of these components is
// using hot module reloading
import { areComponentsEqual } from "react-hot-loader";
{React.Children.map(this.props.children, child => {
          if (areComponentsEqual(child.type, DropdownTrigger)) {
            return React.cloneElement(child, {
              onClick: ev => {
                this.setState({ menuHidden: !this.state.menuHidden });
              }
            });
...
```

on build -> extraResources in applications/desktop/package.json we would need to include the path to this bundled kernel
similar to how we do the bundled js kernel, we need to write a kernelspec for the bundled kernel that is embedded as part of the app

. Our base store is now proper Redux, paired with redux-observable. The way to cancel async actions is through other actions:
`` js
dispatch(
  (actions) => Observable.timer(1000)
    .map(() => ({ type: 'TIMER_COMPLETE'}))
    .takeUntil(
      actions.ofType('ABORT_TIMER')
    )
    //actions.ofType('ABORT_TIMER')is equivalent to
    //actions.filter(action => action.type === 'ABORT_TIMER')`
);
// elsewhere in your code you can abort with a simple dispatch
dispatch({ type: 'ABORT_TIMER' });
```

. Next steps to follow up on (for this and later tests):
Apply the take operator to the observable from createPagerActions:
js
const pagerActions$ = createPagerActions('1', msgObs).take(1);
This is so that the observable "finishes" (otherwise it would stay open forever). This will make more sense at the bottom of this comment.
Create an Array of the actions
js
const actions = []
Then the three callbacks to subscribe should get fully used:

onNext - should push each action onto actions
onError - should fail the test (errors should not happen here)
onComplete - pass done as the callback

js
pagerAction$.subscribe(
  (action) => actions.push(action),
  (err) => expect.fail(), // Should not error
  () => {
    // In reality, you want to verify each action within actions
    // Since we used `take` though, that's kind of silly.
    const action = actions[0]; 
    const expected = [{ source: 'page', data: { 'text/html': 'this is a test' } } ];
    expect(action.id).to.equal('1');
    expect(action.pagers.toJS()).to.deep.equal(expected);
    done();
  }
)

. iopub and shell are both Subjects, created like this:
js
/**
 * Helper function for creating a subject from a socket
 * @param {jmp.Socket} socket the jmp/zmq socket connection to a kernel channel
 * @return {Rx.Subject} subject for sending and receiving messages to kernels
 */
export function createSubject(socket) {
  const subj = Subject.create(createSubscriber(socket),
                              createObservable(socket));
  return subj;
}
When you chain off of it (not shell.send), you're applying functions to create new observables/streams.

For codebase style, this goes against our flux principles
For testing, you can't assume that the module is in the same state. Every single function in here now has access to these variables as part of the module closure.
For modularity reasons -- you can't use this module now to publish multiple gists with one single page app; every single notebook document would have the same gist ID and gist URL

js
function kernelSpec(kernelSpecsRef, kernelSpecName) {
  const kernelSpecs = kernelspecs.byRef[kernelSpecsRef];
  return kernelSpecs.byName[kernelSpecName];
}

This is a precedence order for webpack to choose a key from a package's package.json to determine where to accept the main of the package. Classically, this is main in node apps:
{
  "name": "wat",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "author": "Kyle Kelley <rgbkrk@gmail.com>",
  "license": "BSD-3-Clause"
}
Some people have been setting another field for ES6 code, jsnext:main:
{
  "name": "wat",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "jsnext:main": "src/index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1"
  },
  "author": "Kyle Kelley <rgbkrk@gmail.com>",
  "license": "BSD-3-Clause"
}

. To start (read: beta), we would have all our configuration options "hidden" in the nteract.json file. We would have them documented in a release README but there would be no preferences panel for users to graphically change their configuration. Similar to what I did with the theme configuration, we would have a defaultCellType attribute in the ConfigRecord. The Add New Cell keyboard shortcut would be replaced so that instead of adding a new code cell by default it would add a new defaultCellType cell. Also, we would read from the config when the notebook component is mounted to figure out what the first cell in the notebook should be (right now, it is a code cell).
Later, perhaps for RC, we could add a visual configuration panel where someone could hit nteract > Preferences and a new BrowserWindow would pop out with our preferences pane. Considering the kind of events we want to make configurable now (default kernel, default cell type, theme) the preferences pane will likely just be set up as a form with select dropdowns or whatever other form input makes sense for the data type of the configuration.
Then we would just hook up the onChange event for each select with a dispatch to the SET_CONFIG_KEY  action.

. Jon's summary from #419:
Okay, this post may not be comprehensive, but it's all I've thought about now.
I think you'll want to tackle this in steps,
First
You'll want to make sure that the document state is decoupled from the rest of the application state.  For example, in the following app state:
js
{
  cellPagers: Map,
  cellStatuses: Map,
  channels: Object,
  connectionFile: "/run/user/1000/jupyter/kernel-aaf19a34-c0da-4968-bc2f-d2f8c8ba904b.json",
  executionState: "idle",
  filename: "/home/jon/github.com/nteract/nteract/intro.ipynb",
  focusedCell: "260f6a26-9623-46b7-a83f-ce5f1830d21a",
  github: module.exports,
  notificationSystem: Constructor,
  spawn: ChildProcess,
  notebook: {
    cellMap: {
      "260f6a26-9623-46b7-a83f-ce5f1830d21a": {
        cell_type: "markdown",
        metadata: {},
        source: "a"
      },
      "2bc3af2b-43e7-4284-94a4-1bf135b15110": {
        cell_type: "code",
        execution_count: 2,
        metadata: {
          collapsed: false
        },
        outputs: [ ],
        source: "b"
      },
    },
    cellOrder: [
      "260f6a26-9623-46b7-a83f-ce5f1830d21a",
      "2bc3af2b-43e7-4284-94a4-1bf135b15110",
    ],
    metadata: {
      kernelspec: {
        display_name: "Python 3",
        language: "python",
        name: "python3"
      },
      language_info: {
        mimetype: "text/x-python",
        nbconvert_exporter: "python",
        name: "python",
        pygments_lexer: "ipython2",
        version: "2.7.10",
        file_extension: ".py",
        codemirror_mode: {
          version: 2,
          name: "ipython"
        }
      }
    },
    nbformat: 4,
    nbformat_minor: 0
  },
cellPagers, cellStatuses, focusedCell, notebook probably should be
recorded in the undo/redo stack.  It may make sense to sort the state (this is
something we'll have to do when we get to implementing RTC anyways):
js
{
  appState: { ... },
  userState: {
    cellPagers
    cellStatuses
    focusedCell
  },
  documentState: {
    notebook
  }
}
Second
You'll want two stacks in the application state, undo and redo.  
js
{
  appState: {
    undo: [],
    redo: [],
    ...
  },
  userState: {
    cellPagers
    cellStatuses
    focusedCell
  },
  documentState: {
    notebook
  }
}
and two corresponding reductions, SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT and 
SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT.  SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT takes the current userState
and documentState and stores it in the appState under an undo stack.  For 
example, this would result in:
js
{
  appState: {
    undo: [
      {
        userState,
        documentState,
      },
    ],
    redo: [],
    ...
  },
  userState: {
    cellPagers
    cellStatuses
    focusedCell
  },
  documentState: {
    notebook
  }
}
You'll want to have sane limits on the number of recorded undo and redo actions.
SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT does the same thing but into the redo stack.
Lastly, the corresponding action for the SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT reducer should
have a flag that optionally clears the redo stack (via a CLEAR_REDO reducer).
Third
Create UNDO and REDO actions & reductions.
UNDO action will do the following:
- abort if undo stack length = 0
- SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT
- UNDO reduction: pop state from undo stack over userState and documentState
REDO action will do the following:
- abort if redo stack length = 0
- SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT (clear redo = false)
- REDO reduction: pop state from redo stack over userState and documentState
Forth
Call SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT (clear redo = true) at the beginning of relevant, 
top-level user actions.
Fifth
Implement menu items that point to the UNDO REDO reduction actions.
Checklist

[x] Add SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT and SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT reducers
[x] Add tests for SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT and SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT reducers
[x] Add CLEAR_FUTURE reducer to erase entire future stack (stack of redos)
[x] Add tests for CLEAR_FUTURE
[x] Add clearFuture flag to SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT
[x] Add tests for SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT with clearFuture flag
[x] Add UNDO and REDO reducers for popping items of past and future stack
[x] Add tests for UNDO and REDO reducers
[ ] Identify notebook actions that should trigger an push to the past stack
Delete cell
[ ] Remap Undo and Redo menu options
[ ] QA test entire thing

. OK! I think this is good to be merged. I did some QA and it seems to be working as intended. You can currently undo and redo cell deletions, additions, and sticky celling. More actions can be added as it makes sense.
Here's a quick overview of how it works.
1. SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT appends items to the past stack.
2. triggerUndo middleware calls the SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT reducer on store.document if action.type is one of the actions that is considered undoable.
3. UPDATE_DOCUMENT overwrites store.document with the newDocument passed to it.
4. When the user hits undo, the last items is selected from the past stack and set to UPDATE_DOCUMENT. Then SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT is called to add it to the redo stack. Then UNDO is called which pops the last item off the stack.
5. When the user hits redo, the last item is selected from the future stack and passed to UPDATED_DOCUMENT.
Anyways, I think this is good for review and entry into master and we can iterate on it from there.

. OK. I reworked this a little bit from.
{
  app: {}
  documentMetadata: {
    past: [],
    future: [],
    filename: '',
    document: {}
  }
}
to
{
  app: {},
  metadata: {},
  document: {},
}
I did this for a couple of reasons.
1. I read the Redux docs a little bit more and learned that there really isn't a way to do the undo/redo thing across parts of the state tree without referring to the other part of the subtree.
2. I couldn't get the nested reducer thing to work, but that might be because I am a newb.
So the next best thing I figured is to move the information that document needs to know that isn't pertinent cells or the actual document to a metadata subtree. That way, when that subtree has to (irrevocably) be passed to the document reducers, we are at least passing the most pertinent information and not the entire app subtree.

I closed the PR I was working on (#1055) to start off a clean slate with implementing a solution for this. It looks like we'll have to manage multiple focused states for the CodeMirror editor and the CodeCell/MarkdownCell so there is lots of fun state juggling to be done. 😛 
. Here are more thoughts on this. Specifically, here is how user intents would map to changes in the state. Let's assume we have a simple document with <CodeCell id="1"/>, <CodeCell id="2"/>, and <MarkdownCell id="3"/> . The two state elements that we have are editorFocusedCell for the cell that has CodeMirror focused and cellFocused for the Cell that is focused.
Let's say the user starts off with {editorFocusedCell: 1, cellFocused: 1}.
1. User presses down arrow, the state is now {editorFocusedCell: 2, cellFocused: 2}.
2. User presses up arrow, the state is now {editorFocusedCell: 1, cellFocused: 1}.
3. User clicks the display area on <CodeCell id="2"/>, the state is now {editorFocusedCell: 1, cellFocused: 2}.
4. User clicks the cell editor on <CodeCell id="2"/>, the state is now {editorFocusedCell: 2, cellFocused: 2}.
5. User presses down arrow, the state is now {editorFocusedCell: 3, cellFocused: 3}.
6. User presses shift+enter, the state is now {editorFocusedCell: 4, cellFocused: 4}.
There are probably other combinations of moving between editor components that need to be considered but I think this is a good representation of how the visual representation can be shown in the component state.
. > I think we want editorFocusedCell to be null in this case. We want focus from the cursor/editor to go away (prevent accidental typing, allow other text input to be used).
Ah yeah! This makes way more sense.

Here's where it's a bit strange (and where you fixed it in #1055). We want to lose focus on any other editors (maybe it doesn't have to be explicit) and allow CodeMirror to do the focusing so the user ends up clicking exactly at the cursor position they want.

Yeah. So I have a feeling I might need to pull some nasties with React to get this working right. Because we would need the Editor to change the state on editorFocused and then that change would have to bubble up the DOM tree to the parent CodeCell, Cell, and Notebook components.

I think you'll want to tackle this in steps, First You'll want to make sure that the document state is decoupled from the rest of the application state. For example, in the following app state: js { cellPagers: Map, cellStatuses: Map, channels: Object, connectionFile: "/run/user/1000/jupyter/kernel-aaf19a34-c0da-4968-bc2f-d2f8c8ba904b.json", executionState: "idle", filename: "/home/jon/github.com/nteract/nteract/intro.ipynb", focusedCell: "260f6a26-9623-46b7-a83f-ce5f1830d21a", github: module.exports, notificationSystem: Constructor, spawn: ChildProcess, notebook: { cellMap: { "260f6a26-9623-46b7-a83f-ce5f1830d21a": { cell_type: "markdown", metadata: {}, source: "a" }, "2bc3af2b-43e7-4284-94a4-1bf135b15110": { cell_type: "code", execution_count: 2, metadata: { collapsed: false }, outputs: [ ], source: "b" }, }, cellOrder: [ "260f6a26-9623-46b7-a83f-ce5f1830d21a", "2bc3af2b-43e7-4284-94a4-1bf135b15110", ], metadata: { kernelspec: { display_name: "Python 3", language: "python", name: "python3" }, language_info: { mimetype: "text/x-python", nbconvert_exporter: "python", name: "python", pygments_lexer: "ipython2", version: "2.7.10", file_extension: ".py", codemirror_mode: { version: 2, name: "ipython" } } }, nbformat: 4, nbformat_minor: 0 }, cellPagers, cellStatuses, focusedCell, notebook probably should be recorded in the undo/redo stack. It may make sense to sort the state (this is something we'll have to do when we get to implementing RTC anyways): js { appState: { ... }, userState: { cellPagers cellStatuses focusedCell }, documentState: { notebook } } Second You'll want two stacks in the application state, undo and redo. js { appState: { undo: [], redo: [], ... }, userState: { cellPagers cellStatuses focusedCell }, documentState: { notebook } } and two corresponding reductions, SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT and SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT. SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT takes the current userState and documentState and stores it in the appState under an undo stack. For example, this would result in: js { appState: { undo: [ { userState, documentState, }, ], redo: [], ... }, userState: { cellPagers cellStatuses focusedCell }, documentState: { notebook } } You'll want to have sane limits on the number of recorded undo and redo actions. SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT does the same thing but into the redo stack. Lastly, the corresponding action for the SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT reducer should have a flag that optionally clears the redo stack (via a CLEAR_REDO reducer). Third Create UNDO and REDO actions & reductions. UNDO action will do the following: - abort if undo stack length = 0 - SET_FORWARD_CHECKPOINT - UNDO reduction: pop state from undo stack over userState and documentState REDO action will do the following: - abort if redo stack length = 0 - SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT (clear redo = false) - REDO reduction: pop state from redo stack over userState and documentState Forth Call SET_BACKWARD_CHECKPOINT (clear redo = true) at the beginning of relevant, top-level user actions. Fifth Implement menu items that point to the UNDO REDO reduction actions. . Hey @jaredly , thanks for looking into this. The problem arises when electron-builder tries to rebuild zeromq.
To rebuild it runs 
npm run install -- --disturl=https://atom.io/download/electron --target=1.4.6 --runtime=electron --arch=x64 --build-from-source
since zeromq uses prebuild this will be expanded to
prebuild --install --preinstall "npm run build:libzmq" "--disturl=https://atom.io/download/electron" "--target=1.4.6" "--runtime=electron" "--arch=x64" "--build-from-source"
The problem is target is a option for prebuilt defining the Node.js version to build against. Hence we get a download error because there is now Node.js version 1.4.6.
@develar Would it be better to use
npm rebuild --disturl=https://atom.io/download/electron --target=1.4.6 --runtime=electron --arch=x64 --build-from-source
instead of npm run install for rebuilding?
. @develar Thanks a lot for your help. electron-builder is working really great for us.
With prebuild one can provide prebuilt binaries for different node versions. For example prebuilt --target 7.0.0 would build the native module against node 7.0.0. Though this doesn't work for electron since prebuild doesn't support the --runtime flag.
One can also rebuild only a specific node module by running npm rebuild <module name>.
I still don't know why the rebuilding works on my machine (OS X) just fine but doesn't work on Travis and AppVeyor. I'll investigate soon.

I did some further testing and unfortunately the ANSI parsing plays only a small part of the performance problem 😕 .
I recorded a performance profile of different Ansi components while executing
python
print("This is tooooooo long :(" * 1000000)

Current master took 9.07 s to render
A functional component with no ANSI escaping renders in 8.34 s:
js
const Ansi = props => <code className={props.className}>{props.children}</code>;
A pure component with no ANSI escaping renders in 8.24 s:
js
class Ansi extends React.PureComponent {
  shouldComponentUpdate(nextProps) {
    return (
      this.props.children != nextProps.children ||
      this.props.className != nextProps.className
    );
  }
  render() {
    return <code className={this.props.className}>{this.props.children}</code>;
  }
}

The performance gain of precomputing the ANSI escape will increase when handling streaming output but this doesn't solve the rendering problem 😕 .
Please note, I only recorded the profiles once so I don't claim any statistical significance but it's clear to see that removing the ANSI parsing won't fix the rendering performance issues.
I'm happy to upload the recorded profiles if someone wants to investigate further.. Since this doesn't solve the problem, I think we can close it for now.. Just tried out this branch :tada:

The same should be true for jest since we use a moduleMapping to enable it to read the source files. . I checked, it's not required anywhere.. It's implicitly used by @nteract/display-area but not directly required.. I think the build:packages:ci command can now be removed since, since build:all:ci handles everything..

. What was the thinking behind switching to MPL? Usually such choice are made with some reasoning behind them so we should check what that was.
As I understand it MPL does not stop you from selling a product based on nteract or even keeping your secret sauce secret. Doing the legal legwork seems like a small price to pay (both in terms of $$ and effort) in exchange for a high quality product like nteract. nteract receives support from two companies who have presumably found a way to give back under the current model and further their commercial goals. Another one supports the project by allowing staff to use work time.
The 0MQ guide (it is about the community) contains some reasoning behind why a license that allows remixing is a good choice.
The question of how to make your open-source community sustainable has been getting a lot of attention lately, and has been a struggle for a long time.
Given all this I think a more detailed motivation of why this change would make the community/project better is needed. If only to avoid the slight aftertaste of "please make this easier to use in a commercial setting where we don't wish to contribute back".
. I agree with you that these are real issues for companies that do not wish or can not make their work available under a MPL compatible license. This is a difficult to navigate area for all of us who are trying to create software that uses open-source projects in a commercial setting. As a commercial entity with a business model that is incompatible with MPL like licenses it is in my interest to have work licensed under BSD.
(Speaking purely for myself here) To make nteract sustainable I think nteract needs to work out what is in its long term interest and put those interests first. Anything else makes no sense. These interests might not overlap 100% with those of any other organisation or company. IMO the fastest way to reach a mutually beneficial position is to openly discuss the needs of each party and then make an informed decision.
I would like to see some discussion and then conclusion on what nteract the community thinks is its long term goal and hence what is in its interest. Once this is clear it will be much easier for me to decide whether or not making this change to the license is a good move or not.

. Ok, I added a progress bar that calls update whenever its progress is modified:
``` python
class AutoupdatingProgressBar(ProgressBar):
    @property
    def progress(self):
        return self._progress
@progress.setter
def progress(self, value):
    self._progress = value
    self.update()

```
The horse race at the end now uses this version, so doesn't have to keep calling update.

. This is great. That logic doesn't necessarily belong in the component. That said, it also doesn't necessarily belong in the action. I recently did something like this on a react native app, where I abstracted service calls to an API module. See below:
```
import Services from "../services";
import * as constants from "../constants";
import config from "../../config/development";
export const API = new Services(config.services);
```
The idea here being, the API (or our channels), can be instantiated and exported right from the actions file. That way we get:
- An abstraction to handle non-actiony logic
- A testable service (or channels) layer
- Access to the service (channel) layer right from actions.

@rgbkrk This is correct. regarding keyboard, is not something you should worry about. For any person who uses any other language, the keyboard sends the signals for which key is pressed and it doesn't care what language the user wants to how. This is an example of an Arabic keyboard:
http://www.buypcsupplies.com/images/cat/38558_xlargenss_ndo4203.jpg
Actually your OS takes care of that on its own and maps your keyboard codes to any other language. These is usually a language switch on your screen and/or a keyboard shortcut to to switch languages. This is a screen shot from ubuntu language switch:
http://i.stack.imgur.com/81nDH.png
This the same for all desktop and mobile OS so you really don't have to worry about this.
Regarding your second point about RTL (Right to left) layout, it is easier than what you think.
HTML
<body dir="rtl">
That's it. You might need to do some extra modifications to your CSS. Or you could even have to separate templates one for RTL and one for LTR.

Would it be possible to share the regular notebook's approach? They use MathJax - they make it simpler by only including the parts they need. Turns out if you drop legacy browser support you don't need much of the project - I did something similar with my Atom package  preview-inline.
I definitely do NOT recommend KaTeX - it's fine when you know what maths you will render and plan to keep it simple, but when you want to allow people to write arbitrary math you quickly run into its limitations. I used to include it in preview-inline with a fallback to MathJax, but I found that when you are running locally it doesn't actually make much difference on speed and you end up with the extra complexity of two math rendering libraries

 - first press of shift-tab: show tooltip with a limited height ~10 lines,

 - third press: make it sticky (typing won't dismiss for 10sec, show a clock icon)
 - 4th press, send to pager and dismiss.

FWIW: I've also found more transparent colors work better for readability than the darker colors.. Hi @lukejanicke. You've run into a common point of confusion when using multiple versions of Python. Let's see if I can give you a bit more insight.
Yes, there can be two or more kernel files (Python3, Python2, R, Julia, etc.). For example, on my system, I currently have two kernels installed (Python3 and Python2):
$ jupyter kernelspec list
Available kernels:
  python3    /anaconda3/share/jupyter/kernels/python3
  python2    /usr/local/share/jupyter/kernels/python2
Finding your python versions
Unrelated to the kernels, I can find where I have Python installed by using the which command:
```
carol at cw-pro in ~
$ which python3
/anaconda3/bin/python3
carol at cw-pro in ~
$ which python2
/usr/local/bin/python2
carol at cw-pro in ~
$ which python
/anaconda3/bin/python
``
My system has the/anaconda3/bin/pythonsymlinked (i.e. aliased) to/anaconda3/bin/python3`.
Understanding the nteract recommendation
The pattern that nteract recommends is a one that follows the Python Packaging good practice.
Looking at the recommendation that nteract gives:
python -m pip install ipykernel
python -m ipykernel install --user
In the case of my system, the command python -m pip install ipykernel would be the same as if I typed /anaconda3/bin/python -m pip install ipykernel. When the command executes python, it aliases to /anaconda3/bin/python3. By using python -m pip, you are essentially telling the system to use the version of pip installed with the particular version of Python that which python returns.
For example, python2 -m pip install ipykernel would use /usr/local/bin/python2 to execute pip to install the kernel.

. the output order is based on message order, which corresponds (in IPython) to the order of flush calls. If there's pending output still waiting when a cell finishes, IPython calls:
python
sys.stdout.flush()
sys.stderr.flush()
If you call flush yourself, you can influence the order:

ipykernel 4.3 flushes asynchronously, so you will get some time-sensitive ordering if there's enough time between writes:

Which also demonstrates that we don't merge the streams, so there's a newline on every switch because we put each stdout/stderr switch in divs. This is not an accurate representation of stream output in a terminal, so if you wanted to do a better job, you could do something with spans for the switch instead of divs. Alternately, you could completely ignore the difference between stdout and stderr, which is what a terminal does.
. > that diverges from the notebook format
There's two things here:
1. does running the notebook in nteract produce the exact same notebook as the existing notebook app
2. does it produce a valid notebook
I think it is okay to diverge from the existing notebook implementation on some things like this. For instance, the current notebook chooses to merge consecutive stream outputs (from the same stream), but not doing so is perfectly valid, and indeed we made this change in the notebook for performance reasons without changing the notebook format.
In nteract, you could provide merged rendering of stream output by either
1. matching the collation behavior of the existing notebook in the data structure, just merge them for rendering, or
2. actually discarding stderr information, and turn the notebook into purely stdout, matching the primitive behavior of terminals.
My first inclination is toward (1), but if you want to get rigorous terminal-emulation of things like carriage returns (Jupyter's implementation does not behave identically to a terminal), you can't treat them separately at all.
. It would also be cool if you could implement appending output in a way that doesn't require reprocessing the previous output in order to get the state to be correct. In the current notebook, producing stdout with many messages is an $O(n^2/2)$ operation because it has to append the new message, then redisplay the entire stream. I just don't know how to track the terminal state well enough to do that.
. This is awesome.
. nteract doesn't include non-installed kernelspecs. Jupyter special-cases the IPython kernelspec if it hasn't been installed, but nteract chooses (rightly, I think) to not do this. To install the IPython kernelspec, do:
ipython kernel install
If you want to specifically install it in the env, like xonsh has done, specify the prefix:
ipython kernel install --prefix=/home/parleur/anaconda3
. If you install ipykernel from conda-forge, this will already be done.
. Trust mechanics should only be relevant if the loaded output can execute code. Merely displaying a file shouldn't be an issue unless it's in a manner where it might be able to execute javascript. Showing the user their own private ssh keys isn't an issue unless there's js on the page where the notebook author could send that content to themselves, execute kernel code, etc.
. Depending how many repos you want to set this in, there is a team config you can edit to set defaults at the org level.

. You could separate the 'automatically discovered kernels from conda' as a distinct list (sub or sibling), so it looks something like:
- Kernels (+)
  - Python 3
  - Julia
  - conda envs (+)
  - virtualenvs (+)
That way, any auto-discovered kernels are only visible on request, and clearly distinct from properly registered kernels.

. So another way of orchestrating this is:
just have a state_history list, that contains a list of states, and a current_position int that indicates where in history you are. The way I've done this in other settings, a current_location of 0 means you are at the most recent state.
Undo increments current_position, and redo decrements current_position.
Therefore, when accessing the current state:
current_state = state_history[state_history.length - current_position].
Actions that result in a new state do state_history.slice(state_history.length - current_position).concat([new_state]).

. > ... where we don't wish to contribute back
Very rarely does any organisation make changes to active projects which they do not upstream as with each new release they have to integrate all changes. The 0MQ rationale as it is just arguments with not empirical or significant evidence to support their rationale. Share alike licenses do lead to fragmentation of open source projects due to license incompatibilities or asymmetric sharing as you cannot re license.
Also we have to be in line with reality. Many organisations have license whitelisting and also contractual clauses about code ownership and licensing. In these if the license is not whitelisted or incompatible with contractual obligation you cannot use it. This mostly affects outsourcing and contracting and more acute in outsourcing where contractual obligations are more stringent. In addition, more legal scrutiny and compliance on IP related issues become more costly depending of the dependencies you use. In case of prototypes and demos legal negotiation of these happen before entering into a contract hence upfront overheads increase before being assured of a contract hence it is more rationale to keep costs and potential of legal related questions to a minimum.
This is a minor annoyance with MPL and not the main issue. MPL can be used in commercial setting there you link to the compiled code. Issue comes in non compiled code like JS, HTML. Say you put a logo in the HTML what license coves this modified page. Since the image is separate it need not be MPL in which case what is the rationale of sharing the HTML without the image does the image need sharing also and becomes MPL? If you recreate the HTML with the logo then this is a form of copying hence the file you create is MPL. If you look into the source to see how X is done or integrate to implement / integrate new components Y then Y becomes MPL as you might have to use non trivial part in X to implement Y. Say I want to embed a cell evaluation into another application then studying how this is done and in the current file and implementing this by the same person will become copying unless a 3rd person comes in between to write a specification on how the integration is done. In an sharealike project it s a legal risk to look at the code learn how something is done as by implementing what you learned through looking at the code means the code will become tainted. If you use an IFrame or canvas to embed this will this combined canvas becovered under MPL? IFrame maybe not but forms of embedding / partial embedding this is problematic. None of these issues have be tested in court so lawyers can argue at length and then send you the bill. So best route is to have the option where you can use without have to jump over many hurdles or too costly or risky to use.
. > can weigh in but vote is not mandatory
I have included a list or other uses who might be interested in the project (contributors to sister projects and forks) but not contributors to this project. They have contributed to the project hence for the purpose of the license change their vote is not necessary in case they cannot be contacted or do not vote. They have begin CCed as a courtesy to make them aware of this issue than just limiting it to the project contributors so they can raise their issues or concerns if needed.
Anyway I removed the particular wording.
. I removed the classifications. 
Also please record your vote by clicking on the relevant box.
. Though nteract is open source for integration purposes if you look at the code there is a chance what you develop will become MPL. Also there are reasonable about of JS and HTML which will stay MPL.  E.g. Also there is a chance if https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen integrations similar to that of this project and no documentation on the contrary clear room process was followed the some of the code may become MPL without anybody thinking mainly due to the uses familiarity of code in nteract .  (I am just giving this as an example.) Similarly if this is integrate by studying some of the code into another project this might become tainted without a clean room design and worst without anybody's knowing. In commercial closed should projects involuntary training may not become an issue as there is little chance that this can be discovered and legally enforced. Bigger issue is if the code is open source or there is an intention or obligation to release under a different license (say ASL 2.0) where any similarities can easily be scrutinized and found in case of integration code and can be argued as copied. Also there is very difficult to ascertain if is any is actually "copied", could be legally held as copied or not copied, from external parties. Even in commercial closed source setting it always help to ensure the code is not encumbered by possible legally gray areas. In case there is a CLA and one party owns the code incase there is accidental tainting then you have to negotiate with only one party. In case there is no CLA these issues cannot be resolved as there might be many parties from whom you should get agreement. So permissive licenses work better greater good.

. Okay I figured it out!
. Commander.parse doesn't like undefined as an argument. If you go ahead and hack your index.js code in src/main 
const program = require('commander');
const version = require('../../package.json').version;
process.argv[1] = ''
program
  .version(version)
  .option('-k', '--kernel [kernel]', '')
  .parse(process.argv);
it will run. I imagine newer versions of commander have fixed this problem. 
We can go ahead an iterate over argv to check for undefined and replace it with the empty string as a hacky fix?
. It also might be worth considering moving to vorpal? https://github.com/dthree/vorpal/
Update: after playing around with vorpal, I give up!
. @rgbkrk @captainsafia  if you run ./nteract 'any string here', I think it will open an untitled notebook. If you run ./nteract 'any string here' 'name of file in your path here' it will open your file. 
Another current error is that if the specified file doesn't exist in the path it will hang and nothing will open.
. Pair programmed with @captainsafia and we came to the conclusion that commander eats the first argument in an attempt to resolve the name of the node app that is being ran. 
Under the tutelage of @captainsafia, I tried to play around with process.argv to extract the notebook info ourselves, but in reality we should probably go ahead and understand a tool like commander or vorpal better to get the appropriate behavior. 
I'll come back tomorrow with fresh eyes in an attempt to have an elegant fix. 
. Ahah! I fixed the problem by editing one line of code in node_modules/commander/index.js changing line 456 to 
  var parsed = this.parseOptions(this.normalize(argv.slice(1))); from var parsed = this.parseOptions(this.normalize(argv.slice(2))); makes everything behave swell.
I know this isn't how we want to go about fixing the problem, but it helps us understand whats going on. Edit: I neglected to mention that I added program._name...
```
program._name = 'nteract';
program

. @estevanjantsk, do you use a command line text-editor like vim?

If so, for the future you, you can go in and edit your commits with git rebase -i HEAD~4. You use your text editor see each commit in the form of pick <commit SHA> 'commit message'. 
From here you look at what you want to change, in this case it might be the commit simply named 'changes'. Rename this by changing 'pick' to 'reword'. After this step, exit the interactive editor. From here you will be taken to a prompt to write a new message. You can update it to what we want from there. When you're satisfied with your changes, you're going to have to 'rewrite history' and use git push origin <branch_that_you_were_working_on> -f

. So I think there are few ways to go about fixing this. The way that would lead to the quickest fix would be to add some work  in Display. The notebook contains a cellMap, which is an ImmutableJS data structure. To get data from it you use functions that are a part of that library https://facebook.github.io/immutable-js/. 

The code in src/notebook/reducers/document: 
``` javascript
[constants.TOGGLE_OUTPUT_EXPANSION]: function toggleOutputExpansion(state, action) {
    const { id } = action;
return state.updateIn(['notebook', 'cellMap'], (cells) => cells.setIn([id, 'outputExpanded'],
  !cells.getIn([id, 'outputExpanded'])));

```
takes the state of the notebook, and the id of the cell you want to change, and returns a new immutable data structure where the output expanded boolean is the opposite of what it previously was. What you want to do is something similar, but check if the outputExpanded boolean is different from that of the config, and if so, use that boolean instead. There might be some other fix that is easier and/or more sensible but this should at least point you in some possible direction to go to fix it.
