AlJohri:
@rgbkrk one really nice feature of the jupyter web interface is that using the CLI, if I run: jupyter notebook analysis.ipynb within a virtualenv, it will automatically use the virtualenv's kernel without having to run python -m ipykernel install. I find that running ipykernel install can quickly end up with a ton of kernels in nteract's drop down menu since I use a virtualenv for each project (related #1041, https://github.com/nteract/nteract/issues/1576#issuecomment-331669619)
is there any way that running nteract analysis.ipynb within a virtualenv could automatically detect that its being run from within a virtualenv and start with the virtualenv's kernel if it exists? I know that running jupyter-kernelspec list within the virtualenv is able to find it:
$ pipenv run jupyter-kernelspec list
Available kernels:
  python3    /Users/johria/.local/share/virtualenvs/hss-gPwjJtJU/share/jupyter/kernels/python3
I do understand that this is a little more of an advanced user edgecase but, it would be great to sort of implicitly support this kind of usage when triggered from the CLI but don't surface it in the GUI in anyway. so in the end, I can run something like:
envdir envs/local pipenv run nteract analysis.ipynb
envdir creates a subshell with the environment variables defined in envs/local and pipenv creates a subshell using the virtualenv. thus nteract would start from a shell with an active virtualenv and should ideally be able to find the kernel accordingly

Are you running nteract from Windows and wanting to use your Python environments installed on your ubuntu subsystem?. Should be possible I think, you will probably have to edit kernelspecs yourself.
When nteract loads it's looking for kernelspec files which define kernel details (name, location, etc).
When you load nteract on Windows I think nteract is checking the Windows location but your kernelspecs are installed on the Linux subsystem.
The Windows user location is %APPDATA%\jupyter\kernels which on mine is C:\Users\<name>\AppData\Roaming\jupyter\kernels
The Linux user location for kernelspecs is ~/.local/share/jupyter/kernels
You can try and copy your kernelspecs from Linux location to the Windows location and then try to launch nteract again. Windows needs to be able to access and launch Python from the linux subsystem file location. Check out the kernel.json file to make sure Windows can interpret the file location.

Note: In the existing notebook shift-enter will execute and move focus to the next cell (possibly creating one in the process) whereas ctrl-enter will execute the cell, leaving focus in the same cell but displaying the newly calculated output below.. xref: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab_app/issues/48. From a user perspective it's very valuable to be able to search your command history. As a point of comparison in ipython/spyder you can start typing a command, press the up-arrow and it will cycle through all previous commands starting with that text. In nteract the UI would necessarily have to be slightly different as the up/down arrows are used to move between cells.
I can see two possible solutions to this:
  1. Use a modifier key - e.g. ctrl-up arrow
  2. Create a separate History-Palette dialog similar to the notebook's Command-Palette. This dialog would list the history of commands from the most to least recent and would be filterable as you started typing.
IMHO I think option 2 would probably fit in more smoothly with a UI such as nteract.
. I'm not sure what a design/mockup would involve but I'll note my current thoughts in case they're useful.
I really like my idea above of a History Palette which you could bring up with e.g. Ctrl-Shift-H. Similar to the Command Palette it would have a text box which would dynamically search/filter the results. The text box could initially be populated with the contents of the current line when the palette was invoked.
I think this is a more powerful UX than cycling through the history with the up-arrow so would probably be my preference. It might still be nice to have the ability to cycle through history with e.g. Ctrl-↑ but the History Palette should be sufficient on it's own.

Is this a known issue? Has anyone actually been able to build the latest version on win64?. I've found that javascript and Windows paths can often cause issues. I don't really have the JS chops to debug it myself though :/
. The last build I did with npm worked. After the change to yarn I haven't been able to build on Windows which was why I was curious if anyone had been able to or if it was something specific to my setup. I just updated nteract to the latest git master, updated yarn to the latest 0.24.4 and the build worked. So maybe there was an issue with Yarn on Windows which has now been fixed?. Pretty low priority I'd imagine but I think it's useful to have an issue to at least record it.. It would still be nice to have feature parity with the notebook/jupyterlab. Just tested and it works great with Ctrl-Space so I'll close this as resolved.

I suppose the real issue here is the supporting of tab for completion (we have an issue somewhere for that...)

I found a couple of issues #963, #1870 - nothing specific about tab-completion.. xref: #263 . This is still the case in the latest 0.3.2. Just pinging this issue to make sure it hasn't been forgotten...
By-and-large I find nteract pretty slick! ...but I'm hesitant to recommend it to less experienced colleagues if the standard ? help functionality doesn't work - that's pretty important for new users.. With the latest 0.8.4 I still can't seem to bring up the function signature tooltip. Do you know the key combo for windows - I can't seem to trigger it. 
It would be nice if it were Shift-Tab as in jupyterlab to better make use of muscle memory. . Potentially dup of #1584.
I'd really like to have this functionality so I'm wondering if this is a new-contributor friendly issue or if it requires a deeper understanding of the nteract architecture? The initial goal would be to just add some hard-coded shortcuts and punt on the customization part for now.. I'm not advocating for a Command Mode for nteract as I know and understand the reasons why the core devs don't want to go down that route, however in the notebook the command mode allows you to perform operations on the cells themselves which can be a huge productivity boost as compared to having to use the mouse.
My suggestion would be to have operations which act on the cells themselves to use the Ctrl-Shift modifier. The three most important shortcuts I'd like to add would then be:
 * Ctrl-Shift-A - Add cell above
 * Ctrl-Shift-B - Add cell below
 * Ctrl-Shift-D - Delete cell
You could keep Ctrl-Shift-N as an alias for Ctrl-Shift-B but I think having the shortcuts mirror those of the notebook gives a huge benefit in terms of muscle memory and makes transitioning between JupyterLab, the classic Notebook and nteract much easier.
Other shortcuts which would be useful:
 * Ctrl-Shift-Y - Change cell to code
 * Ctrl-Shift-M - Change cell to markdown
 * Ctrl-Shift-R - Change cell to raw
Dragging and dropping cells is a nice UI but it would also be good to have keyboard shortcuts to do the same. My suggestion would be that Ctrl-Shift-{click} would allow you to select one or multiple cells and then Ctrl-Shift-C would copy them, Ctrl-Shift-X would cut them and Ctrl-Shift-V would paste any copied cells.
My initial goal and highest value-added (for me) would be to just implement A/B/D. Would be interested to hear your thoughts on the above ideas and the concept of using Ctrl-Shift to indicate operations on cells.. I see Ctrl-Shift-X will cut a cell - cool! I can't seem to paste cells though with Ctrl-Shift-V or even just Ctrl-V

Would "add cell" default to code or to what your last cell type was?

I'd just follow what JupyterLab does in this instance to minimize any cognitive dissonance when switching

Since movement between cells can be done with only up/down alone, I'd be tempted to use ctrl-shift-up to create cells?

Similarly, I'd be inclined to not stray too far from the shortcuts already used in the notebook - hence my suggestion of A/B. I could just be particularly bad at context-switching but I do currently find myself constantly polluting my nteract notebooks with random As and Bs! :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye: 
Assuming you can select multiple cells I would use Ctrl-Shift-Up to include the cell above in the current selection if the current selection was above the anchor cell or to remove the last cell from the selection if the selection was below the anchor cell and vice-versa for Ctrl-Shift-Down
Since that's probably as clear as mud, here's a gif of the intended behaviour:

...i.e. Ctrl-Shift-Up/Down should behave similarly to extending a selection of cells in a spreadsheet using Shift-Up/Down
Ctrl-Home would be a useful shortcut to go to the top of the document.. NB: I'm running the latest nteract release on Windows - 0.2.0. I'll add another - Ctrl-Shift-Z undo last cell operation . In particular, undo delete cell :sob: . Looks like the update did work!

The trouble is the way that CSS is loaded. Here, the theme CSS is added first (via src/notebook/components/notebook.js) and the main stylesheet is loaded after (via src/notebook/index.js). CSS is cascading, so (assuming equally-specific selectors) the value declared last wins. To make the theme changes "win", we need to either get more specific (like prepending the .notebook class or adding !important after the value). If the CSS files were reordered so that the theme CSS came last, the theme would override the main CSS without additional selectors/specificity.
I just did some quickie testing on my end and variables can be used (in main.css) before they are declared (in the theme's CSS), so we should be safe to change the order!

. ## UI Update

Inline render
I've now got the inline widget expanding/retracting the cell as needed. 

In particular I like that it only shows the signature / first line initially as some docstrings can be huge and so would be unwieldy in a tooltip. You can expand the tooltip to see the full docstring in a scrollable window.

Thanks very much for your thoughts, @dhirschfeld! I really like this functionality, too. The gif shows how it can be annoying to automatically expand a large docstring -- I will try to incorporate handling this going forward.

You can also send it to the pager which gives you way to view two signatures/docstrings at the same time. IMHO, the ideal UI here would be to be able to "pin" the tooltip so that it became a movable/draggable floating, window and you could pin as many tooltips as you wanted to your workspace.

I like the idea of potentially making it draggable/sticky. The limitation for this at the moment is that it is rendered inline in the cell, but I am definitely open to exploring it.
Additionally, I like @Carreau's idea of using css to break outside the cell (instead of expanding it), but have had trouble making it happen with the css. I'll keep trying, though -- thanks @Carreau!

Thanks for testing nteract! I think the following should work, but someone else please add to it if I missed something.
Dev install
To install the dev version so that you can just double click a notebook to open, you can run the following command,
bash
npm run dist
And then install the package from the newly created dist directory. After that you should be able to double click a notebook.
Kernels
Unfortunately, virtualenv and conda env kernels are not installed by default, but you can install one in the following way,

First, activate the env (example with conda below with env named amueller)
bash
source activate amueller
Then, install the kernel,
bash
python -m ipykernel install --name amueller --display-name "Python scikit-rocks"
where amueller is the internal Jupyter name and Python scikit-rocks is the name that will actually be displayed.. Thanks greenkeeper!. My pleasure!. Thanks Lukas!. Thanks!. >You may also need to add the module to our webpack config (look where zeromq is listed).

/**
 * Turn any output that was in JupyterMessage into a record

export function outputFromMessage(msg: JupyterMessage<any,any>): OutputRecord {
  switch (msg.header.msg_type) {
    case stream.StreamType:
      return stream.streamRecordFromMessage(msg);
    case displayData.DisplayDataType:
      return displayData.displayDataRecordFromMessage(msg);
    case executeResult.ExecuteResultType:
      return executeResult.executeResultRecordFromMessage(msg);
    case error.ErrorType:
      return error.errorRecordFromMessage(msg);
    default:
      // $FlowAllowFeatureDetection: At runtime, allow fallback
      return unrecognized.unrecognizedRecordFromMessage(msg);
  }
}

After the provider refactor, I think we should spend some time making our components more composable. Right now, we make a lot of assumptions about what a notebook should and should not have. For example, we embed the StatusBar into the Notebook but what if the end user wants to embed their own status bar? What if the user wants to display different buttons in the Cell Creator menu? Today, we don't support either of those use cases. I really like Victory as an example of a completely composable library - it makes no assumptions on what is included in a chart and leaves the decision completely up to the user.
We should also think about integrating our CSS into JS to allow users to pass in custom styles through a style prop that will override our defaults. I'm most familiar with Aphrodite because it's really similar to React Native StyleSheet, but I'm open to any other libraries here. Here's an example of what it would look like:
```
// our default
const ColoredDiv = ({}) => 
const styles = StyleSheet.create({ coloredDiv: { backgroundColor: 'red' } })
// we can concatenate their styles passed through the style prop onto our existing styles (it can take an array)
// it works like object assign so whatever is last is what is rendered

// div will render blue
``. Thanks again for another great Flow PR 🎉 !. Awesome! Thanks again for all your work on this feature. :shipit: . Sure! 😀 Providers are only concerned with application level state and are connected to the Redux store. Views are unconnected to the store and should only be concerned with view level state isolated to that component (things like toggling a button or in our case, hiding a dropdown). This pattern helps us enforce separation of concerns.
Another reason we can't hide the dropdown on our provider is because we're using refs to invoke methods on the Dropdown component. Refs are destroyed when their children are destroyed, so we have to sync up establishing the ref with ToolbarView's render method instead of ToolbarProvider's.
Provider:
js
clearOutputs() {
  const { dispatch, id } = this.props;
  dispatch(clearOutputs(id));
}
// pass down this method to the view through props
View:
```js
// define a method called clearOutputs on the class & bind it in the constructor
clearOutputs () {
  this.dropdown.hide()
  this.props.clearOutputs()
}
render () {
   this.clearOutputs()} />
}
```

. nbagg / notebook is going to be replaced by ipympl which uses ipython widgets.  I am a bit unclear on how these interact with nteract still.. I am very excited about this :smile: 
To get this started, https://matplotlib.org/users/event_handling.html#event-connections is the user events we expose out to user (some of which are generated internally).  I think sorting out how get the information we need for them back to the python side is a good way to frame this discussion.
The most important 'interactive' ones are probably {'button_press_event', 'button_release_event', 'key_press_event', 'key_release_event'}, 'scroll_event' would be a nice to have. This mean we need a channel to get mouse button presses (along with where the mouse is when clicked and special casing for double click) and keyboard key presses (along with all of the modifiers) coming back from the front end.
'resize_event' is essential is we need to let the Matplotlib side know if the front end re-sizes the figure. 
We internally generate pick events from the button press and scroll events.
If we got that + hacked up the rubber band for zoom on the client side I think we would have 60% of the use cases covered (zoom, animation, picking, resizing, mouse/keyboard events), but no panning and no lasso, keyboard events won't carry location information.
The next thing would be the {'figure_enter_event', 'figure_leave_event'} which is just if the mouse is over the canvas or not.
The next thing we need is the motion_notify_event which is where the user mouse is at any given time.  From that we the internally generate {'axes_enter_event', 'axes_leave_event'}.  Once you have motion_notify_event you get panning, keyboard events have the right location, and lasso will work..

@chendaniely, I maintain a couple of PKGBUILDS for Electron-based apps that are built with electron-builder. Please see the attached PKGBUILD. Note, please remove ".txt" for both of these files (GitHub wouldn't let me upload without an extension).
PKGBUILD.txt
LICENSE.txt
Pasted below for good measure: 
```
Maintainer: chendaniely chendaniely@gmail.com
Contributor: Conor Anderson conor@conr.ca
pkgname=nteract-bin
pkgname=${pkgname%-bin}
pkgver=0.1.0
pkgrel=1
pkgdesc="Interactive literate coding notebook"
url='https://nteract.io'
arch=('x86_64')
depends=('alsa-lib' 'gconf' 'gtk2' 'libxss' 'libxtst' 'nodejs' 'nss' 'python')
makedepends=('gendesk')
license=('BSD-3-Clause')
source=("${_pkgname}${pkgver}_amd64.deb::https://github.com/nteract/nteract/releases/download/v$pkgver/nteract_0.1.0_amd64.deb"
        "LICENSE")
sha256sums=('38d56954443a1debad628d1d76750e9c20f32932bfcb6eb632651211c3f6e1b2'
            '9810f3d57c552d3b3f6c82cb3b6f3402d6faf94fc5a63067fe28360fb3b8b688')
prepare() {
  gendesk -f -n --name="${_pkgname}" --pkgname="${_pkgname}" --pkgdesc="${pkgdesc}" --exec="${_pkgname}" --categories="Development"
}
package() {
  cd "$srcdir"
  ar xf "${pkgname}${pkgver}_amd64.deb"
  tar xf data.tar.xz
# Place files
  install -d "${pkgdir}/usr/lib/${_pkgname}"
  cp -a "${srcdir}/opt/${_pkgname}/"* "${pkgdir}/usr/lib/${_pkgname}"
# Symlink main binary
  install -d "${pkgdir}/usr/bin"
  ln -s "/usr/lib/${_pkgname}/${_pkgname}" "${pkgdir}/usr/bin/${_pkgname}"
# Place desktop entry and icons
  desktop-file-install -m 644 --dir "${pkgdir}/usr/share/applications/" "${srcdir}/${_pkgname}.desktop"
  install -dm755 "${pkgdir}/usr/share/icons/hicolor/"
  cp -R "${srcdir}/usr/share/icons/hicolor/"* "${pkgdir}/usr/share/icons/hicolor/"
# Place license files
  for license in "LICENSE.electron.txt" "LICENSES.chromium.html"; do
    install -Dm644 "${pkgdir}/usr/lib/${_pkgname}/${license}" "${pkgdir}/usr/share/licenses/${_pkgname}/${license}"
    rm "${pkgdir}/usr/lib/${_pkgname}/${license}"
  done
  install -Dm644 "${srcdir}/LICENSE" "${pkgdir}/usr/share/licenses/${_pkgname}/LICENSE"
}

thomasballinger:
There's a margin-bottom: -11px; style that isn't being applied to these extra-tall cells in the class="CodeMirror-sizer" div.
This seemed to be caused by https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/blob/5fc55e8227b3c0d1d8e3178a45fbb37f6f581e48/src/display/update_display.js#L46 not clipping enough because there doesn't seem to be a scrollbar present; a scrollbar should cause a difference between display.scroller.offsetWidth and display.scroller.clientWidth, but when this runs the first time these values are the same.
So maybe some kind of timing issue with scrollbars? Edit: it's definitely some kind of race condition; wrapping the resizing code in maybeClipScrollbars in a setTimeout(function(){...}, 0) fixes the problem.
Next step is probably to create a minimal repro for codemirror or to figure out if we're doing something we aren't supposed to.. Thanks! I can update this tonight.. hoop-jumping 3.

  Interactive literate coding notebook!. I've manually tested the installation workflow and deemed that it works, although the packages are not elegant in that some of the metadata is lacking of incorrectly formatted. All the user-facing stuff that involves icons and clicking on this works as expected.
The minimum workflow for testing the system-wide install is:
npm run dist    # a user would normally download the package from the github release page
sudo dpkg -i dist/nteract_0.0.15_amd64.deb   # could be by double-clickg the .deb file

It can then be removed with:
apt-get remove nteract

. > - [ ] Determine apt-get dependencies and add those to package.json. This would allow automatically installing eg. pip along with the nteract package.
While doing this I realized that most dependencies are packages as .so files inside the package, and end up in /opt/nteract/.
.deb archive linters will complain about using embedded libraries, as most correct way is to list those libraries as dependencies in the package metadata, so that the libraries can be installed from their own packages. Using .so files works fine, it's just not the preferred way.
I have a feeling that if it's  at all possible to avoid shipping libraries as .so using electron-build, it may be non-trivial (or at leat it's non-obvious to me). For the sake of this pull I'm not going to set this package to depend on other packages, and just let the libraries be shipped as .so inside of the package.. > - [ ] Are there man pages already written, or some documentation similar to it? typing man nteract in a terminal should give usage documentation.
I haven't been able to figure out how to place arbitrary files in arbitrary location using the current build system, so I'm not sure how this can be done. At the moment nteract --help covers pretty much everything, since there aren't that many command line options as far as I'm aware. I may out-of-scope this task as well for now.. Thanks for the responsive feedbak. I think I've made all the suggested changes. I'm fairly happy with this as a proof-of-concept, although there is till much room for improvement. 
Here is a quick screen capture of a test install on a almost clean install on the latest version of Ubuntu (16.10).
I can make individual issues for things that require further work. For example the menu item Help > Install Shell Commands attempts to alter /opt/nteract/resources/bin/nteract-env, which is owned by root:root and requires sudo privilege (besides, installing the .deb installs the shell command as well).
I've done some linting on the .deb and ad-hoc testing of the install and removal process. There was some strange edge-case weirdness a few times, but nothing I've been able to reliably reproduce for debugging.
I'm ok, with this being merged in its current state, but also open to suggestions.. I just tested this on a 32-bit (i389) ubuntu setup and it seems to work fine there also.. The 0.0.16 was there by accident, I didn't realize what npm version did exactly. I'll remove it.. I've now removed the offending npm version commits and tags.. I got a new update to  GitKraken today, and that process was quite nice as well, as far as self-updating applications on linux go.
On Linux their process is something like:

initial installation of the .deb
check for updates on application startup
notify user if there are updates available
the notification has a "download .deb" button, clicking it downloads a new .deb
when the download is complete, there is a "show in file manager" button.
double click the .deb to open the system package installer and replace the current install
back to 1.

This flow would probably be fairly straight-forward to implement using github releases mechanism to host the .deb, and I assume github has an API to check for new releases, since they seem to have most things. :thinking: . .deb packages include postinst maintainer scripts that are execute as root after installing the package. The current .deb created by electron-builder uses postinst to symbolically link nteract to PATH ln -s /opt/nteract/nteract.sh /usr/bin/nteract
This script could be used used to add an entry to /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nteract.list in order to configure itself for automatic updates via the system update service (assuming updates are distributed using a package archive, not by self-update GitKraken style).
As an Ubuntu user this is the way I would personally perfer things to work. The installaiton flow would be:

Download a .deb from the nteract.io website or a github releases page
Install the package using the system installer like any other deb packages.
The installer postinst script adds an entry to sources.list.d for nteract
The system update service updates my nteract install along with all other software automatically whenever new updates are pushed to the package archive.

Some responses

Precursors > Refactor components to remove Redux logic

If I'm understanding this right, you're looking to pass down dispatch-y props to child components? I've found that using connect and just defining mapStateToProps and mapDispatchToProps liberally helps keep logic inside the file you'd like it to be in. I.e., if you end up interacting with a component and something breaks, it's more likely that the problem is in that component file. I also prefer this for tests. Anyways, just some thoughts.

We should also think about integrating our CSS into JS to allow users to pass in custom styles through a style prop that will override our defaults.

I wonder if in-lining styles will couple React code a little too tightly with the style? I'm not sure how you're planning on doing the overriding of things, but a well-organized set of scss files (using the 7-1 pattern https://sass-guidelin.es/) can be pretty clean! That said, I've never actually tried doing css --> js and have blindly followed articles like this.

. ## Problem
We need to get to parity with "classic" Jupyter with nteract's jupyter
extension. Right now, we really only have a component in core called
NotebookApp that handles the editing of a notebook.
Jupyter Extension requirements
In our Jupyter extension, we can have the following cases:
Note that we don't necessarily know the type from the contents api ahead of
time. In this case, we may need to get the file and then redirect.
^^ Is it possible to make a request for just the metadata about a file? I.e.,
not get the whole file? Probably not something that needs worrying about yet,
but it'd be wasteful to fetch the whole file and then just redirect.
```
/edit/ && { type: "notebook" }
/edit/ && { type: "file" }
/edit/ && { type: "directory" }
/view/ && { type: "notebook" }
/view/ && { type: "file" }
/view/ && { type: "directory" }
/tree/ && { type: "notebook" }
/tree/ && { type: "file" }
/tree/ && { type: "directory" }
```
Plan
```
/edit/ && { type: "notebook" } >> 
/edit/ && { type: "file" } >> ??
/edit/ && { type: "directory" } >> redirect(/tree/)
/view/ && { type: "notebook" } >> redirect(/edit/)
/view/ && { type: "file" } >> ??
/view/ && { type: "directory" } >> redirect(/tree/)
/tree/ && { type: "notebook" } >> redirect(/view/)
/tree/ && { type: "file" } >> redirect(/view/)
/tree/ && { type: "directory" } >> 
```
I plan to make a new Directory component inside /core, though I think we
may want to refactor that later if /core ends up too bloated.
I'm not going to handle the File view yet, but I wanted to add it into the
mix for discussion.

Nteract looks very cool and in fact I'm using it even as we speak.  But, to ask the same question in a hopefully less abrasive way: My initial impression of nteract was that it was Jupyter wrapped in some kind of mini-browser that allows it to be used on the desktop.  I was expecting the usage to be exactly like regular Jupyter, but in this desktop interface rather than a web browser.  What this thread made me wonder is whether the scope of nteract is in fact that, or more than that (i.e., aimed at developing a richer interface), or less than that (i.e., aimed at implementing a simplified Jupyter-like interface rather than just straight-up deploying Jupyter in a desktop environment)..

. ## Version 2.3.0 just got published. 
Update to this version instead 🚀 

Release Notes
v2.3.0
Features:

add extensions option to DllReferencePlugin
add warningsFilter to UglifyJsPlugin to hide warnings selectively
add extractComments to UglifyJsPlugin to move kept comments into separate file (i. e. LICENSE file)
validate relative and absolute paths in configuration
validate stats options
allow to match on compiler (name in configuration) in rules

i. e. allows to specify different rules for extract-text-webpack-plugin or html-webpack-plugin


Allow to pass multiple entries via CLI
Performance improvements
CommonsChunkPlugin give errors on incorrect options
add module.strictExportPresence to make missing export an error instead of warning
Compiler emits watch-close event when the watcher is closed
Allow additional compress options in UglifyJsPlugin
empty chunk numbers are not flags in every chunk, this improves caching invalidation

Bugfixes:

OccurrenceOrderPlugin now counts occurrences correctly
Fix cheap-source-maps when combined with ES Modules (lines were offset)
Watcher now detects file deleting correctly
Resolve output path if relative output path is given via CLI
Handle stack traces in errors correctly
Some usages of System now generate valid code i. e. System.global
Dynamic property names are now parsed and can contain webpack stuff (i. e. imports)
Empty enviroment variables are now supported in the EnvironmentPlugin
(Maybe) Fixes chunk loading in IE when script is cached

. ## Version 1.3.3 just got published.

Release Notes
v1.3.3
v1.3.3 (2017-04-07)
🐛 Bug Fix

Support electron version in a string format (#252) (@yavorsky)

Adding electron as a target was an inadvertent breaking change as it no longer
allowed string versions. We added an exception for now, even though it is
inconsistent with other versions. Just as a note, the upcoming version 2.x will
allow both number and string versions.

Ensure const-check plugin order (#257) (@existentialism)

We now force the const-es2015-check plugin to run first (so that it can
correctly report issues before they get transpiled away).
🚀 New Feature

Allow use babel-plugin- prefix for include and exclude (#242) (@yavorsky)

The include and exclude options now allow both prefixed (babel-plugin-transform-es2015-spread)
and prefix-less (transform-es2015-spread) plugin names.
📝 Documentation

Note babel plugin prefix handling in include/exclude (#245) (@existentialism)
Fix README: debug option shows info in stdout. (#236) (@Gerhut)

🏠 Internal

Add simple smoke-test (#240) (@existentialism)
Add prepublish script (@existentialism)

. ## Version 19.6.0 just got published. 
Update to this version instead 🚀 

Release Notes
19.6.0
If you want to build on macOS application for windows, you need to install ... no. Nothing. No need to pollute your developer machine or waste build time on CI server. All required system dependencies (including wine) will be downloaded for you. Except mono, but Squirrel.Windows target in the maintenance mode :)
macOS Sierra (10.12+) is supported, on Travis please set osx_image: xcode8.3.
No plans to support Linux in this way — because for Linux special docker images are provided already.
Yes, it means, that if your app doesn't have native dependencies, you don't need AppVeyor anymore, you can build app for windows on macOS Travis.
Features

mac: upgrade osslsigncode, do not require wine (ed662e8), closes #1713 #1707
nsis: Add flag to force start on silent install (f24c389), closes #1545 #1712

On the one hand, having this information in an easily editable form would be amazingly useful.  
Laying out the information like this would be great for a variety of use cases (quick publication or keeping contact information available to students throughout a tutorial or talk).
But the display and the editing don't need to be handled in exactly the same way and their unification may not be good for all use cases (e.g., I generally don't like editing text at multiple different font sizes… I don't know if others share this dispreference but I am guessing that I'm not alone in this).

there is an issue with remark-math and consistency with the Jupyter ecosystem. Specifically it treats within paragraph $$…$$ as being an inline element, when the rest of the Jupyter ecosystem treats it as a display element.
Here's a catalogue of ways this can diverge (in classic notebook & lab all of these would render as )
Consistent (✔️): 
(newlines) → display:

Inconsistent (❌):
(no newlines) → inline:

(no first newline, yes last newline) →  undefined:

(yes first newline, no last newline) → display + extra $$

Double dollars in inline
Some TeX packages and Markdown processors use double dollars, $$, as a inline token. Remark Math will parse it also properly.
$$\alpha$$

Based on some of the content at this math-in-markdown wiki, it's mostly git related applications based on kramdown (e.g., GitBook, gitter)  that have this convention (where $$…$$ is treated as inline and not a display equation). 
This is not what either notebook or lab uses for its interpretation of math syntax. It also is not, by default, what mathjax itself expects (where $$…$$ is to be treated as a display equation). 
Remark math has a feature that enables something that is somewhat like a display equation if you add the right css, but that seems super fragile.

They use the inlineMathDouble class to keep the same paragraph but to display it as though it were a different paragraph. Notice the spacing for the two cases is different:

smashwilson:
Here's a (completely untested) way to do this with a git subtree:
git subtree add --prefix=packages/${NAME} git@github.com:nteract/${NAME}.git master
This gives you the option of preserving the full git history for the package repo, including contributor credit, blame, and whatnot. If you just want a single commit it accept a --squash argument too.. This works, but to inherit the full history you might want to look at git subtree:

add::
Create the  subtree by importing its contents
  from the given  or  and remote .
  A new commit is created automatically, joining the imported
  project's history with your own.  With '--squash', imports
  only a single commit from the subproject, rather than its
  entire history.. Ohh, wait a minute... the destination prefix already exists in the target repo? Yeah, that changes things somewhat. Hmm. How about something like:

```bash
In nteract/${NAME}
git checkout -b move-to-monorepo
mkdir -p packages/${NAME}
git mv !(packages) packages/${NAME}
git mv .SOMEFILE packages/${NAME} # Catch the dotfiles
git commit -am 'move stuff around'
git push origin move-to-monorepo
In nteract/nteract
git remote add subpackage-${NAME} git@github.com:nteract/${NAME}.git
git fetch subpackage-${NAME}
git merge subpackage-${NAME}/move-to-monorepo
``. 🤔 Weeeeird. What kind of conflicts were there? The merge should have constrained changes to thepackages-enchannel-zmq-backend/` subdirectory which doesn't exist on master..

psychemedia:
From a user perspective, part of a related use case comes from a desire to launch an arbitrary  environment accessed via a Jupyter notebook UI.
The environment may be a custom code envt (apt-get and pip dependencies) or may require access to running services (eg a DBMS, or geo tileserver, or etc etc).
One example launcher I'm aware if is O'Reilly LaunchBot: https://blog.ouseful.info/2017/08/30/oreilly-launchbot-like-a-personal-binder-app-for-running-jupyter-notebooks-and-other-containerised-browser-apps/.
williamstein:
I wrote a lot of code to make things very fast (e.g., using static rendering for all but the current focused cell).  It worked in that it was fast... but then I (temporarily) gave up and disabled all that code, since it was too much work re-implementing everything myself given my goals/needs. The problem is that codemirrors static html export is missing much of the functionality of codemirror, and the author doesn't want to implement it, so you end up having to reimplement a lot (e.g., line numbers). 

@williamstein tends to be open to relicensing portions of code for reuse.

I am very open. (Also, this particular code was 100% written by me without any possible ownership issues from employers, so I definitely CAN relicense anything.)

Renovate attempts to detect on a per package file basis and only treats as an app of main is missing or private is true . Well, it’s mostly about build reproducibility, ie avoiding the “so what changed between this build that failed and the one before that worked?” 
Also doing this way ensures that when security updates are released for node that everyone’s cache is broken and they download the correct image rather than using a cached insecure one. 
But of course it’s optional. @rgbkrk ok, noted. FYI, Renovate waits until all "pin" PRs are merged before starting on update PRs, so you will need to merge this or disable Docker renovation. To disable docker, add "docker:disabled" to your "extends" array.. plenty more fish in the sea:

. Actually you can just add this:
"ignoreDeps: ["flow-bin"]
with "ignoreDeps" being at the same level as "extends".. FYI, Renovate will rename the Pull Request titles you have open once you merge this, but it won't regenerate any commits. i.e. won't cause unnecessary duplicate testing on your CI.
However be aware that Renovate automatically regenerates existing branches if there is any conflict, so as you start merging changes to package.json you can expect to see the occasional branch recreated by Renovate in order to automatically resolve those git conflicts.. @rgbkrk right now there's no native way to view all ignored updates in one place, other than using GitHub's search, e.g. https://github.com/nteract/nteract/pulls?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Apr+sort%3Aupdated-desc+is%3Aclosed+%22Renovate+Ignore+Notification%22+author%3Aapp%2Frenovate+.

amcdawes:
On the one had, it seems reasonable to expect the result of _repr_latex_() to return fully-valid LaTeX. On the other hand, that is not what packages currently do (mainly since they've just done what they needed to do in order for it to "just work" in jupyter.. I don't think the implications go that far back in the processing. For this specific case, simply changing _repr_latex_ to return '\mathrm{Quantum~object: dims = [[2], [1]], shape = (2, 1), type = ket}\\begin{equation*}\\left(\\begin{array}{*{11}c}1.0\\\\0.0\\\\\\end{array}\\right)\\end{equation*}' fixes it... in the sense that the text looks correct. It's still parsed by mathjax (which is fine).
~~I think it's reasonable to expect things coming from _repr_latex_() to be stuffed into mathjax... and ask people to plan accordingly.~~
Nevermind, using \mathrm{...} breaks nbconvert so isn't likely to be a workable solution.. I like the idea of a _repr_mathjax and _repr_latex since that respects the differences between the two systems. It seems easy enough to fallback on _repr_latex if there isn't a mathjax method (since that would likely do ok). A bigger issue may be why the behavior in nteract has diverged from jupyter notebook. Packages that define _repr_latex are likely to make sure they work in jupyter (and nbconvert). Seems like the safest bet is to replicate notebook behavior (or coordinate adoption of _repr_mathjax by both projects). @mpacer wrapping with $...$ adds literal $ around the output in nteract 0.7.1. I think this is because nteract is passing all of _repr_latex to mathjax in a math environment already. Essentially, that's why this issue started. It seems like earlier versions did not do that; in 0.6.2 the extra $'s do not appear, and nteract displays the resulted \mathrm formatted strings..

. Caveat: I'm a relative newbie, but wanted to do a little research towards helping this happen, so here's what I found in 10 mins:
The Jupyter kernel API used to have a user_variables entry in the execute request/response, and this was for fetching the list of user-created variables in the current execution stack.
Unfortunately for us, 5.0 of the API (a couple of years ago) removed this, and replaced it with user_expressions. This is for holding and executing code in the kernel's own language that will fetch metadata to go alongside the execute output. It's intended for things like custom prompts.
So, the good news is that it's theoretically possible, and there's a place to put it in the protocol. The bad news is that it's language-specific. For each kernel, you'd need an expression in that language to serialise the complete set of user-created variables. But, hey, you'd only need to define that once per kernel, and you'd have some control over the serialisation, so that might make the front-end easier and more powerful.. @mmagnuski Thanks for that, I didn't know about that project. The code is super clean and readable. Here's what I can tell from a brief browse:

It's mostly TypeScript, and it uses JupyterLab's TypeScript APIs to hook into kernel communication
On initial activation, it sets up some custom functions in the kernel's userspace (currently only supporting a few Python kernels) to do inspection & serialization
(I'm unsure about this bit.) Instead of sending user_expression riders along with each execute request, it sends its own execute request as followup.

(This is a really ignorant question, but: Seeing that it's mostly JS underneath, and it's hooking into the increasingly-popular JS API for JupyterLab extensions... could that same API be exposed in nteract? I realise the UI model's mostly different, but maybe the underpinnings are similar enough. I'm saying this with no idea of what nteract's current API is, or what plans for extension support are, so feel free to ignore.).

I can remove it.. that's not correct. because the package.json's all point to a main file at lib/index.js and types at lib/index.d.ts -- webpack will look for those files and ignores the typescript in src.
Previously this may have been partially obscured by having the paths property set in the base tsconfig.  However, using paths in this way conflicts with composite/build-mode [which requires you to specify all of your files and to keep them under the same root, which is src in each package]. 
. Because we are using packages in a monorepo, all of our tooling (webpack, vscode language support, babel) look for types and source in lib/ not src/.  this means that to even open the project in an IDE without the having it throw errors everywhere, you need to have at least an initial build of your source present. i.e. the first step after installing will always be a clean build anyway.
I think it's worth hooking here so that developers don't immediately hit a speed bump when they first open the project.
. See my note above. Our packages say to look for main and types in lib/ not src/ which means when you import via Webpack, it goes there.  Ditto when you're importing from another package via jest.
FWIW - I think this is probably on balance the best behavior because it means that consuming a package local to the monorepo follows the exact same code path as if you installed the package from npm.
. Thanks that's good to know. I missed that when I looked at the configuration. I'll go back and see if I can figure out why that wasn't working before.. why do we even have the tsc-build process then? It feels like a recipe for ongoing issues to have parallel build infrastructure.. OK. I did some investigating. There seems to be a confluence of things going here:
1- I'm not sure why but it appears that if you have a lib directory in a package, then webpack will prefer to use that code instead of what it finds in src. Once you get into any compiled lib directory, you're in commonjs land using require everywhere and so then it expects all other packages to be compiled also.
2- There isn't really a good way to do a build clean and even when I try to run the build:clean task in each project, it doesn't seem to consistently clean out the old lib directories in non-tsc-based packages.
Thus you end up in a situation where the webpack build is nondeterministic. If you've run a yarn build sometime recently, you can end up with old artifacts included in the build and unexpected errors.
Furthermore, looking at the webpack config it feels like there are a number of overlapping methods in play here to try to resolve various paths in different ways. Further making it hard to reason about how to includes will happen.
To further complicate matters, vscode / tsserver doesn't see any of this custom webpack trickery which means that you must keep at least the built versions of your typescript packages up to date for intellisense to work across packages.  Which gets us back into the original problem of webpack getting confused if you have some packages built.

I have a proposal on how to fix all of this. Maybe I should write an RFC as an issue and we can discuss it there?
